Abstract: Reliability is one of the key features that is sought after in converter design. Electrolytic capacitors are the most common capacitor type in switching mode power supplies to be used as a DC bus energy storage. However, electrolytic capacitors are known to degrade due to aging. This paper introduces a capacitance degradation detection method for a step-down DC-DC converter that is based on introducing a voltage transient to the output voltage. The method is based on analyzing the voltage step response. The method was verified to be feasible with experimental tests with a grid connected step-down DC-DC converter. © assigned jointly to the European Power Electronics and Drives Association & the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE).

Authors: Abdel-Monem M., Hegazy O., Omar N., Trad K., Bossche P.V.D., Mierlo J.V.
Title: Lithium-ion batteries: Comprehensive technical analysis of second-life batteries for smart grid applications
Source title: 2017 19th European Conference on Power Electronics and Applications, EPE 2017 ECCE Europe
Affiliations: Vrije Universiteit Brussel, ETEC Dept., MOBI Research Group, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, B-1050, Belgium; Department of Vito, Unit of Energy Technology, Boeretang 200, Mol, 2400, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Abdel-Monem, M., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, ETEC Dept., MOBI Research Group, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, B-1050, Belgium; Hegazy, O., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, ETEC Dept., MOBI Research Group, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, B-1050, Belgium; Omar, N., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, ETEC Dept., MOBI Research Group, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, B-1050, Belgium; Trad, K., Department of Vito, Unit of Energy Technology, Boeretang 200, Mol, 2400, Belgium; Bossche, P.V.D., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, ETEC Dept., MOBI Research Group, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, B-1050, Belgium; Mierlo, J.V., Vrije Universiteit Brussel, ETEC Dept., MOBI Research Group, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, B-1050, Belgium
Abstract: In the upcoming years, thousands of battery storage systems will be decommissioned from electric vehicles. Instead of recycling or sending them immediately to landfills, these battery systems could be reused in other applications, such as grid or end-user applications. Second-life batteries are still expected to be capable of storing and delivering substantial energy. It is possible that they could satisfy the requirements of stationary applications. Indeed, the total lifetime value of the battery will increase when the remaining capacity of batteries can be invested to meet the requirements of other energystorage applications. Consequently, the price of battery systems will be decreased, which helps the widespread commercialization both of electric vehicles and grid storage systems. However, there is an increasing need to investigate the potential of using second-life batteries in stationary applications (i.e., electric supply, ancillary services, grid system, end user/utility customer, and renewable integration). While some used battery technologies are now ready for commercial demonstration, there is no clear market structure to demonstrate the benefits of the used batteries for grid applications. While the need and opportunities for second-life batteries are obviously a number of gaps and limitations currently constrain the adoption of using the second-life batteries for grid-scale applications. Therefore, in this article, a comprehensive technical analysis is provided by addressing all aspects of a battery's life cycle to investigate the feasibility of reusing the retired EV batteries in stationary applications. This manuscript provides the experimental verification of the proposed solutions in order to face the main technical challenges, such as: Lack of standards and models, aggravation of the aging process, difficulty testing and sorting staggering number of batteries, and inefficient of circuits and operational scenarios. Furthermore, Battery model is designed and verified by using MATLAB/Simulink environment. © 2017 assigned jointly to the European Power Electronics and Drives Association and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE).

Abstract: The paper proposes an electronic-smoothing inductor (ESI) as an energy storage element in currentsource PFC based LED drivers. In comparison with the passive inductor approach, the required inductance value of the overall driver circuit can be significantly reduced such that better power density and efficiency can be achieved. The derivation of different structures of current-source LED drivers by duality principle is also discussed in this paper. The idea is validated by a single-stage, current-boost PFC pre-regulator for low-power LED lighting applications. © assigned jointly to the European Power Electronics and Drives Association & the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE).

Title: Power Generation on-board Aircraft using an Air-Powered Turbine Generator and Battery Interface System
Source title: 2017 19th European Conference on Power Electronics and Applications, EPE 2017 ECCE Europe
Affiliations: Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, PO Box 395, Pretoria, 0001, South Africa; Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Stellenbosch University, Private Bag XI, Matieland, Stellenbosch, 7602, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Coetzer, A., Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, PO Box 395, Pretoria, 0001, South Africa; Turner, G., Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, PO Box 395, Pretoria, 0001, South Africa; Mouton, T., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Stellenbosch University, Private Bag XI, Matieland, Stellenbosch, 7602, South Africa
Abstract: The design and implementation of a prototype hybrid power generation system, consisting of a ram air turbine (RAT) generator and an energy storage unit, is presented. The system is intended as a mechanism to supply additional or emergency power on-board an aircraft. Here we present the design, manufacture and testing of a synchronous rectifier required to interface an asynchronous generator to a dc bus. The dc bus connects to a battery of electrochemical cells through a bidirectional DC-DC converter. The DC-DC converter functions to regulate the dc bus voltage by utilising a double control loop strategy with an inner current control loop and outer voltage control loop. The power delivered to the dc bus from the generator is controlled as a function of the battery voltage, dc bus current and generator shaft speed. The control strategy used by the prototype circuit is presented in this paper along with simulation and experimental results. © assigned jointly to the European Power Electronics and Drives Association & the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE).

Authors: Kroics K., Zakis J., Suzdalenko A., Husev O., Tytelmaier K., Khandakji K.
Title: Operation possibility of grid connected Quasi-Z-Source Inverter with energy storage and renewable energy generation in wide power range
Source title: 2017 IEEE 1st Ukraine Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering, UKRCON 2017 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Institute of Industrial Electronics and Electrical Engineering, Riga Technical University, Riga, Latvia; Department of Biomedical Radioelectronics Apparatus and Systems, Chernihiv National University of Technology, Chernihiv, Ukraine; Department of Electrical Power and Mechatronics, Tafila Technical University, Jordan
Authors with affiliations: Kroics, K., Institute of Industrial Electronics and Electrical Engineering, Riga Technical University, Riga, Latvia; Zakis, J., Institute of Industrial Electronics and Electrical Engineering, Riga Technical University, Riga, Latvia; Suzdalenko, A., Institute of Industrial Electronics and Electrical Engineering, Riga Technical University, Riga, Latvia; Husev, O., Department of Biomedical Radioelectronics Apparatus and Systems, Chernihiv National University of Technology, Chernihiv, Ukraine; Tytelmaier, K., Department of Biomedical Radioelectronics Apparatus and Systems, Chernihiv National University of Technology, Chernihiv, Ukraine; Khandakji, K., Department of Electrical Power and Mechatronics, Tafila Technical University, Jordan
Abstract: In renewable energy generation systems, energy storage is needed not only for short-term smoothening of the electric supply, but also to supply power when there is no generation for a longer period of time. The Quasi-Z-Source Inverter (qZSI) enables the integration of energy storage easily in addition to the other energy source mainly used for output power smoothening. In this paper the possibility to integrate energy storage in qZSI structure is analyzed in case when the input voltage is low or when battery is the only source of energy. The operation limits of the converter and possible solutions to extend the operation range are analyzed theoretically and by means of simulations in PSIM software. Results show that low input voltage limits the operation range of energy stored qZSI; modified circuits that can be used to avoid these limitations are proposed. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: energy storage; grid tied inverter; quasi-Z-source converter; single phase inverter
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Renewable energy resources; Electric supply; grid tied inverter; Operation limits; Quasi-z-source converters; Renewable energy generation; Single-phase inverters; Source of energy; Z-source inverter; Electric inverters

Authors: Ivakhno V., Zamaruiev V., Styslo B., Kosenko R., Blinov A.
Title: Bidirectional isolated ZVS DC-DC converter with auxiliary active switch for high-power energy storage applications
Source title: 2017 IEEE 1st Ukraine Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering, UKRCON 2017 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Industrial and Biomedical Electronics, National Technical University, Kharkiv Polytechnic Institute, Kharkiv, Ukraine; Department of Biomedical Radioelectronic Apparatus and Systems, Chernihiv National University of Technology, Chernihiv, Ukraine; Department of Electrical Engineering, Tallinn University of Technology, Tallinn, Estonia

Abstract: This paper describes topology and control algorithm of a bidirectional isolated converter with controlled semiconductors at the voltage-fed and current-fed parts. A bidirectional switch connected in series with the transformer winding at the current-fed side features zero-current switching and allows achieving zero-voltage-switching of transistors at the voltage-fed side by utilising leakage inductance of the isolated transformer. The topology is proposed for high power battery or fuel cell systems. The proposed ideas are verified with simulations in MATLAB and evaluation prototype. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Wang P., Zhang T., Li R.
Title: A new hybrid MMC with integrated energy storage
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Zhang, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Li, R., Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: As the penetration level of wind power increases, displacing conventional power generation with wind power will reduce the inertia of power system and decrease the frequency stability. Energy storage devices with only 5% energy storage of wind farm’s rated capacity can produce the same virtual inertia as a same capacity synchronous generator. To reduce the additional costs of individual energy storage devices, this paper proposes a new hybrid modular multilevel converter (HMMC) with integrated battery energy storage. It has the capability of smoothing battery current and reducing battery voltage, while possessing DC fault ride-through capability with no additional costs in comparison with previous work on energy storage MMC. Voltage balancing, control strategy and parameter design are discussed in the paper, while simulation results illustrate three working States (charging, discharging, and idle) of battery and power balancing of submodules. If the proposed new submodule accounts for half of the cells, the new HMMC is able to provide sufficient virtual inertia for the wind farm with capacitor voltage requirement only 5% higher than conventional MMC. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: DC fault ride-through; High-voltage DC transmission system (HVDC); hybrid modular multilevel converter (HMMC); Offshore wind power; Virtual inertia
Index Keywords: Cost reduction; DC power transmission; Electric batteries; Electric power transmission; Electric utilities; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Power converters; Secondary batteries; Wind power; Dc fault; High voltage dc (HVDC) transmissions; Modular multilevel converters; Off-shore wind power; Virtual inertia; HVDC power transmission

Authors: Yang X., Xue Y., Chen B., Yang F., Zheng T.Q., Wang Y.
Title: Enhanced modular multilevel converter based battery energy storage system
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing, China; State Key Laboratory of Large Electric Drive System and Equipment Technology, Tianshui Electric Drive Research Institute Co., Ltd., Tianshui, China

Abstract: This paper proposes an enhanced modular multilevel converter based battery energy storage system (EMMC- BESS) for interfacing low voltage batteries to the medium or high voltage grids. Besides the distributed battery integration functionalities and the inherited advantages of traditional MMCs, EMMC- BESS also provides the DC fault handling capability. Based on analysis of operation principles, the control algorithms are developed for power control and the balancing of battery state of charge (SOC). Moreover, typical DC fault is taken into consideration for further analyzing the DC fault blocking mechanism. Feasibility of the proposed topology and the control strategies are verified by test results. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Do N.N.L., Taberner A.J., Ruddy B.P.
Title: Design of a linear permanent magnet synchronous motor for needle-free jet injection
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: Auckland Bioengineering Institute, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Auckland Bioengineering Institute, Department of Engineering Science, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Do, N.N.L., Auckland Bioengineering Institute, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Taberner, A.J., Auckland Bioengineering Institute, Department of Engineering Science, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Ruddy, B.P., Auckland Bioengineering Institute, Department of Engineering Science, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand
Abstract: Needle-free jet injection allows delivery of liquid drugs through the skin in the form of a narrow fluid jet traveling at high speed, minimizing the risk of accidents. The use of a controllable actuator to drive this process has many advantages, but the voice coil actuators previously used are too large and heavy for practical use with common injection volumes (~1 mL). We instead propose a compact slotless tubular linear permanent magnet synchronous motor design for jet injection. The design was determined by utilizing a semi-analytical electromagnetic modeling technique to predict the performance of any given motor design, an optimization scheme for the motor mass at a given power dissipation, and an automated routine for estimating cogging force using finite-element analysis. A prototype motor was constructed, with a nominal mass of 322 g, a stroke of 80 mm, and a target operating power of 1.2 kW; experimental data show that the motor constant is within 10 % of the target, and that the cogging force is in close agreement with the model. The design methodology explained here shows the benefits to integrated design optimization of both the actuator and the load, particularly in systems that drive fluid pressure loads, and also opens the door to controllable injector designs for larger volumes. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Moore S., Barendse P.
Title: Online condition monitoring of lithium-ion batteries using impedance spectroscopy
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Cape Town, Cape Town, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Moore, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Cape Town, Cape Town, South Africa; Barendse, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Cape Town, Cape Town, South Africa
Abstract: Lithium-ion batteries are at the forefront of energy storage technology due to its high energy density and durability; they are however expensive and must be operated within certain limits to prevent damaging them. Thus, there is a need for improved condition monitoring to increase its life expectancy and performance. In this work, Electrochemical Impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is implemented using a bi-directional DC-DC converter to characterize the lithium-ion battery under near realtime conditions. EIS is a widely used technique for characterizing electrochemical cells, however, due to long procedural time involved, it is limited to offline (laboratory) testing. This paper investigates several types of impedance spectroscopy (IS) techniques that can be performed while a battery is connected to a load, to characterize the lithium-ion battery and hence determine and monitor its State of Health (SoH) and State of Charge (SoC). The main contribution of this work is the implementation of a multi-sine broadband impedance spectroscopy (BIS) technique in a switching converter to reduce measurement time and thus enable near real-time IS measurement. The proposed technique is carried out using the associated battery converter without additional components incorporated into the converter. Results obtained show that the BIS implemented on the switching converter is effective at characterizing the battery's impedance spectrum as compared to the conventional EIS. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Broadband impedance spectroscopy; DC-DC converter; Impedance spectroscopy; Lithium-ion

Authors: Mao M., Wang Y., Yue Y., Chang L.
Title: Multi-time scale forecast for schedulable capacity of EVs based on big data and machine learning
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: Research Center for Photovotaic Engineering System, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, China
Authors with affiliations: Mao, M., Research Center for Photovotaic Engineering System, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, China; Wang, Y., Research Center for Photovotaic Engineering System, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, China; Yue, Y., Research Center for Photovotaic Engineering System, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, China; Chang, L., Research Center for Photovotaic Engineering System, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, China
Abstract: The application of large-scale electric vehicles (EVs) into the future smart grid may bring about serious power quality problems. But EVs can provide ancillary services for the power system as distributed energy resources through Vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology. The fast and accurate prediction of schedulable capacity (SC) of EVs is the first step to enable this benefit. In this paper, two different time scales schedulable capacity forecasting (SCF) methods are proposed, including the real-time SCF method and a day head SCF method. Firstly, the real time of SCF of EVs is calculated by collecting the real-time charging or discharging data of individual EVs and a distributed data parallel calculation method to solve problems of the mass data process and storage problem. Secondly, the large amount of results of the real-time SCF, is used as historical data, to train the SCF models one day ahead by parallel decision tree regression algorithm (PDTR) and parallel random forest regression algorithm (PRFR). These proposed methods are evaluated by the real time operation data involving 521 EVs in the filed in China on Spark. The test results show the advantage of using big data technology in the ability and speed of dealing with large-scale data, and PDTR is faster and better than PRFR in one day ahead SCF. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Bampoulas A., Karlis A.
Title: A novel dynamic demand control of an electric vehicle integrated in a solar nanogrid with energy storage
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Democritus University of Thrace, Xanthi, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Bampoulas, A., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Democritus University of Thrace, Xanthi, Greece; Karlis, A., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Democritus University of Thrace, Xanthi, Greece
Abstract: Electric Vehicles (EV) have become increasingly popular in recent years and are regarded as an important means to alleviate air pollution problems The broad connection of EV batteries to the grid along with household scale renewable energy sources penetration creates the need for local unified control systems to support the future smart grid. In this paper, an Energy Storage Management System was designed and modeled via Matlab/Simulink in order to accommodate Vehicle to Grid (V2G) functionalities in a residential nanogrid, which incorporates a Photovoltaic system, an installed energy storage system and domestic loads together with an EV battery. The designed control system ensures the user's driving requirements satisfaction, providing ancillary services to the utility grid through an autonomous distributed control, customized to the user's needs. The simulation results for all case studies considered show that the proposed control scheme integrates V2G technology so that the nanogrid follows the mains frequency providing ancillary services to the Bulk Power System via frequency regulation. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Gevorgian V., Muljadi E., Luo Y., Mohanpurkar M., Hovsapian R., Koritarov V.
Title: Supercapacitor to provide ancillary services
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Authors with affiliations: Gevorgian, V.; Muljadi, E.; Luo, Y.; Mohanpurkar, M.; Hovsapian, R.; Koritarov, V.
Abstract: Supercapacitor technology has reached a level of maturity as a viable energy storage option available to support a modern electric power system grid; however, its application is still limited because of its energy capacity and the cost of the commercial product. In this paper, we demonstrate transient models of supercapacitor energy storage plants operating in coordination with run-of-the-river (ROR), doubly-fed induction generator hydropower plants (HPP) using a conceptual system control architecture. A detailed transient model of a supercapacitor energy storage device is coupled with the grid via a three-phase inverter/rectifier and bidirectional DC-DC converter. In addition, we use a version of a 14-bus IEEE test case that includes the models of the supercapacitor energy storage device, ROR HPPs, and synchronous condensers that use the rotating synchronous generators of retired coal-powered plants. In this paper, we emphasize the control coordination among the components of the power system. The control actions must be coordinated and prioritized based the capability, response time, the power rating, and the energy content of the components. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Ding G., Zhang S., Shan J., Gao F., Gu X.
Title: Autonomous control of active power electronics loads for frequency control of islanded microgrid
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, China; Grid Maintenance Department, State Grid of China Technology College, Jinan, China; State Grid Zaozhuang, Power Supply Company, Zaozhuang, China; School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, China
Authors with affiliations: Ding, G., School of Electrical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, China; Zhang, S., Grid Maintenance Department, State Grid of China Technology College, Jinan, China; Shan, J., State Grid Zaozhuang, Power Supply Company, Zaozhuang, China; Gao, F., School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, China; Gu, X., School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, China
Abstract: Frequency control is significant to maintain the stability and reliability of islanded microgrids. Generation side controls, e.g., virtual synchronous generator control and droop control, have been widely adopted to stabilize the frequency of islanded microgrid. However, this is not ideal method due to the capacity limitation and power fluctuation of distributed generation(DG). Meanwhile, energy storage system(ESS) installation will significantly increase the investment of microgrid since the high construction cost. In this paper, an autonomous control scheme of active power electronics loads(APELs) was proposed to make the APELs regulate their power consumption in proportion to their adjustable power capacities based on the frequency monitored locally. With the participation of the APELs, the power supply-demand imbalance can be solved and the microgrid frequency deviation can be maintained within the allowable range. Therefore, the additional power reserve of DGs and energy storage systems are not required. Meanwhile, the proposed control scheme is distributed control algorithm for APELs. As a consequence, the central controller and the communication links can be saved. The effectiveness of the proposed control is demonstrated via Matlab simulations in islanded microgrid. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Active Power Electronics Loads; Autonomous Control; Frequency Control; Microgrid

Authors: Wang H., Wang H.
Title: An active capacitor with self-power and internal feedback control signals
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: Center of Reliable Power Electronics (CORPE), Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Pontoppidanstraede 101, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Wang, H., Center of Reliable Power Electronics (CORPE), Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Pontoppidanstraede 101, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark; Wang, H., Center of Reliable Power Electronics (CORPE), Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Pontoppidanstraede 101, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark
Abstract: This paper proposes a concept of two-Terminal active capacitor implemented by power semiconductor switches and passive elements. The active capacitor has the same level of convenience as a passive one with two power terminals only. A control strategy that does not require any external feedback signal is proposed and a self-power scheme for gate drivers and the controller is applied to achieve the two-Terminal active capacitor. The concept, control method, self-power scheme, efficiency, and impedance characteristics of the active capacitor are presented. A case study of the proposed active capacitor for a capacitive DC-link application is discussed. The results reveal a significantly lower overall energy storage of passive elements and a reduced cost to fulfill a specific reliability target, compared to a passive capacitor solution. Proof-of-concept experimental results are given to verify the functionality of the proposed capacitor. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Feedback; Control methods; Control strategies; Feedback signal; Impedance characteristics; Internal feedback; Passive elements; Power semiconductor switches; Proof of concept; Power control

Authors: Chen M., Xiao X., Yuan C., Tao S.
Title: Flexible power control of virtual synchronous generators under unbalanced grid voltage conditions
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Chen, M., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, China; Xiao, X., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, China; Yuan, C., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, China; Tao, S., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, China
Abstract: The stability problems of power electronics interfaced distributed generators with low inertia and damping can be well solved by the virtual synchronous generator technologies. However, when the grid voltages become unbalanced, oscillations in both the real and reactive power will arise with unbalanced voltages and currents of VSG being noticed. This paper proposed a flexible power control method of virtual synchronous generator under unbalanced grid conditions. Firstly the basic principle of the traditional virtual synchronous generator control method is briefly introduced. Then three different control strategies are presented based on control of negative-sequence voltage at PCC in d-q frame. Performance of these three control strategies are compared in PSCAD/EMTDC simulations. Finally, a RTDS-based real-Time digital and physical close-loop experimental test bed is built to verify the proposed control strategy furtherly. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Han M., Jiang F., Li H., Zhou R., Huang Z., Peng J.
Title: An improved voltage balance strategy for renewable generation energy storage system
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410075, China; Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, China
Authors with affiliations: Han, M., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410075, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, China; Jiang, F., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410075, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, China; Li, H., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410075, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, China; Zhou, R., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410075, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, China; Huang, Z., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410075, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, China; Peng, J., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410075, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, China
Abstract: Active voltage balance has been a popular voltage balance method in high power supercapacitor applications. In this paper, an improved active voltage balance strategy is proposed for renewable generation energy storage systems. First, we propose an improved active voltage balance circuit based on the multi-winding transformer. A clamping capacitor is inserted in the primary side of the transformer to provide a better transient performance. Then a simple but efficient control logic is proposed to decide the sequence of cells to be charged. The supercapacitor is modeled as a RC equivalent circuit. Instead of balancing the terminal voltage of cells, we use an constant-current charging method to identify the parameters of supercapacitors, and calculate the equivalent capacitor voltage, which is further used in the voltage balance. Experiment results are provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the design. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Energy storage; Supercapacitor; Constant current charging; Energy storage systems; Equivalent capacitors; Multi-winding transformer; Renewable generation; Supercapacitor application; Transient performance; Voltage balance methods; Equivalent circuits

Authors: Zhu J., Gao F., Liu X., Xiao J.
Title: A control method to mimic synchronous generator characteristics for two-stage converters
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong Province, China; Shandong Electric Power Maintenance Company, Jinan, Shandong Province, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, J., School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong Province, China; Gao, F., School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong Province, China; Liu, X., Shandong Electric Power Maintenance Company, Jinan, Shandong Province, China; Xiao, J., Shandong Electric Power Maintenance Company, Jinan, Shandong Province, China
Abstract: This paper proposes a new control method for two stage converters to realize the virtual synchronous generator (VSG) operation, which also can help eliminate circulating power between energy storage (ES) converters. It is proven in this paper that the proposed method shares stronger resemblances with synchronous generators (SGs) than traditional VSG in aspects of power conversion process and mathematical model. In order to implement it safely, necessary constraints are also considered and discussed. Inverters using this method can operate with higher efficiency and less capacity of energy storage. Additionally, the stability analysis, parameters design, and control issues (including virtual inertia/damping control, frequency/voltage control, multi-machine coordination operation, and so on) of the two-stage systems based on the proposed VSG can be solved in a similar pattern as conventional power systems. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Shi G., Sun Y., Yuan W., Han H., Su M., Hou X.
Title: A decentralized SOC balancing method in cascaded h-bridge based storage modules
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, China
Authors with affiliations: Shi, G., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, China; Sun, Y., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, China; Yuan, W., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, China; Han, H., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, China; Su, M., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, China; Hou, X., School of Information Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, China
Abstract: Due to different initial state of charge (SOC) of energy storage system, the SOC of cascaded storage module is unbalanced in microgrid. Many conventional methods realize SOC balance of cascaded storage module based on centralized communication. In this paper, a decentralized SOC balancing method is proposed without any communication. In this scheme, the modified P-f curves are changed by the local SOC information in real-time, which can change the out-inputting power for balancing SOC. Moreover, regardless of charging mode or discharging mode, the unified SOC balancing is guaranteed without changing control structure. Compared with Centralized communication, this scheme has a higher reliability and fault tolerance. The stability of this scheme is verified through small signal analysis of the complete system. Finally, the effectiveness of SOC balancing and transient response are verified through simulations. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Gu X., Gao F., Aamir F., Liu X., Xiao J.
Title: Redistributed pulse width modulation of MMC battery energy storage system under submodule fault condition
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong Province, China; Shandong Electric Power Maintenance Company, Jinan, Shandong Province, China
Authors with affiliations: Gu, X., Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong Province, China; Gao, F., Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong Province, China; Aamir, F., Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong Province, China; Liu, X., Shandong Electric Power Maintenance Company, Jinan, Shandong Province, China; Xiao, J., Shandong Electric Power Maintenance Company, Jinan, Shandong Province, China
Abstract: Battery energy storage system based on modular multilevel converter (MMC-BESS) has many advantages such as easy expansibility and high reliability. With multiple submodules (SM), the corresponding SM fault ride-through method is mandatory to reduce the construction redundancy and improve the operational reliability. This paper proposes a redistributed pulse width modulation (R-PWM) method for MMC-BESS to ride through the SM fault, which has excellent performance in different modulation indexes and can reduce the number of redundant SMs in MMC-BESS. Matlab/Simulink simulations and experimental results are presented to verify the performance of the proposed method. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery energy storage system; modular multilevel converter; Redistributed pulse width modulation; Submodule fault

Authors: Soliman H., Davari P., Wang H., Blaabjerg F.
Title: Capacitance estimation algorithm based on DC-link voltage harmonics using artificial neural network in three-phase motor drive systems
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Control Engineering, Arab Academy for Science and Technology, Cairo, Egypt; Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Soliman, H., Department of Electrical and Control Engineering, Arab Academy for Science and Technology, Cairo, Egypt, Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark; Davari, P., Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark; Wang, H., Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark; Blaabjerg, F., Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark
Abstract: Reliability of dc-link capacitors in modern design of power electronic converters is an important aspect that needs to be considered. The requirement of applying condition monitoring for health status estimation in many reliability-critical applications have been a focused demand. The existing capacitor condition monitoring methodologies are suffering from shortcomings such as, low estimation accuracy, extra hardware, and increased cost, and thereby, they are rarely adopted by industry. Therefore, development of new methods that are based on advanced software algorithms and data processing techniques requiring no extra hardware will be more attractive to industry. In this paper, a condition monitoring methodology is proposed and applied on the dc-link capacitor in a three phase Front-End diode bridge motor drive. The proposed condition monitoring methodology estimates the capacitance value of the dc-link capacitor based on Artificial Neural Network (ANN) algorithm. Two ANNs (ANN1 and ANN2) are proposed, trained and evaluated based on time-domain and frequency-domain parameters. Experiments are conducted to validate the proposed methodology and the effectiveness of the proposed method is examined through an error analysis. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Fan D., Hu S., He X., Wang Y., Chen M.
Title: Modeling and state-space feedback design of the battery current controller for the energy stored quasi-Z-source inverter
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Fan, D., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Hu, S., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; He, X., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Y., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Chen, M., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: A battery-assisted qZSI features buck/boost characteristic by introducing shoot-through states. It makes full use of the fluctuant power, which generated from photovoltaic or fuel cell, by the energy-stored battery paralleled to the quasi-Z-source capacitor. Previous studies discussed the steady state performance and energy storage management for batteries. However, the dynamic tracking performance is not well studied. In this paper, a four-order model is proposed and the bandwidth limitation is analyzed by the maps of the closed-loop poles. A high bandwidth battery current controller is fulfilled then based on the state-space feedback technology. Finally, the simulation and experimental results validate the efficiency of the proposed control method. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Li H., Chen M., Yang B., Blaabjerg F., Xu D.
Title: A fast fault protection based on direction of bus-side capacitor discharge current for a high-surety power supply
Source title: 2017 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2017
Affiliations: Institute of Power Electronics, Zhejiang University, Zheda Road 38, Hangzhou, China; Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Li, H., Institute of Power Electronics, Zhejiang University, Zheda Road 38, Hangzhou, China; Chen, M., Institute of Power Electronics, Zhejiang University, Zheda Road 38, Hangzhou, China; Yang, B., Institute of Power Electronics, Zhejiang University, Zheda Road 38, Hangzhou, China; Blaabjerg, F., Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, 9220, Denmark; Xu, D., Institute of Power Electronics, Zhejiang University, Zheda Road 38, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: A short-circuit fault protection strategy based on the direction of bus-side capacitor discharge current for a high-surety power supply, known as Super Uninterruptable Power Supply (Super UPS), is studied in this paper. It consists of multiple energy sources and storage components. All energy sources and storage components are connected to a common DC bus through converters in the system. If a short-circuit fault occurs in the DC port of any energy source or storage component including its converter, it will result in a rapid drop of the DC bus voltage. Therefore an effective fault protection strategy is necessary to keep the uninterruptable power for the critical load. In this paper, the characteristics of the short-circuit fault are analyzed first. Then, a fast short-circuit fault locating and isolating strategy based on the direction of the discharge current of the busside capacitors of the converters is proposed. Finally, the proposed protection strategy is verified by simulations. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Directional fault protection; High-surety power supply; Short-circuit fault protection; Super uninterruptable power supply (Super UPS)

Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, University of Ilorin, Nigeria; Dept of Telecommunication Sciences, University of Ilorin, Nigeria

Abstract: Energy fuels the growth and development of any country, and as such effective monitoring, measurement, billing and access control is imperative. This paper presents a device that uses the evolving Internet of Things (IoT) technology in the design and implementation of an Internet based prepaid energy meter often referred to as smart meters. The energy measurement and billing system is automated. The system employs the ATMega328p and ESP8266 to operate a dual core microprocessor unit with one core dedicated to energy sensing and measurements, while the other handles the network connectivity, storage, computations and overall system performance. This work uses the HTML5 technology to develop a highly interactive mobile and web frontend Graphic User Interface (GUI) application that allows for consumers to have access to monitor and control their consumption pattern while the utility companies can monitor and control customers and their billing systems. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Kusakana K.
Title: Impact of demand profiles on grid-interactive photovoltaic systems in Bloemfontein: A case study
Source title: 2017 IEEE AFRICON: Science, Technology and Innovation for Africa, AFRICON 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Central University of Technology, Bloemfontein, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Kusakana, K., Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Central University of Technology, Bloemfontein, South Africa
Abstract: In this paper the impact brought by different demand sector profiles on the daily operational cost and optimal scheduling of grid connected photovoltaic system with bidirectional power flow is analysed for the specific case of Bloemfontein in South Africa. For this purpose, residential, commercial and industrial daily load curves are used to estimate daily load demands. For comparison purposes, three load profiles representing the demands from the residential, commercial and industrial sectors, have been used and normalized to display the same daily energy consumption level with different demand patterns. The results of the simulations, obtained using Matlab 2016, have revealed that for the same energy consumption and renewable resources, the running expenses of any proposed scheme are mainly dependent on the demand sector. Consequently, it can be recommended that in Bloemfontein and South Africa in general more focus should be on implementing grid-connected renewable hybrid energy with storage system in the commercial and industrial sectors instead of in the residential sector. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Demand sectors; Distributed generation; Grid-connected; Optimal scheduling; Time-of-Use

Authors: De Beer B., Rix A.J.
Title: Network strengthening using storage support: A case for increasing remote generation
Source title: 2017 IEEE AFRICON: Science, Technology and Innovation for Africa, AFRICON 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electric and Electronic Engineering, University of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, 7600, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: De Beer, B., Department of Electric and Electronic Engineering, University of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, 7600, South Africa; Rix, A.J., Department of Electric and Electronic Engineering, University of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch, 7600, South Africa
Abstract: Weak network characteristics make it difficult to maintain grid compliance which, in its turn, restricts photovoltaic (PV) installation capacity. An energy storage system (ESS) combined with an on-load tap changing (OLTC) transformer is proposed as a solution. PV power plants are often located at remote locations where the electric network is weak. A weak network model is defined and simulated, showing that installation capacity is limited. A control system is developed to allow the ESS and the OLTC transformer to work in conjunction with each other to maintain grid code compliance. The proposed solutions is simulated to show plausibility. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Gaunt C.T.
Title: Implications of renewable energy intermittency for power system supply planning
Source title: 2017 IEEE AFRICON: Science, Technology and Innovation for Africa, AFRICON 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Cape Town, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Gaunt, C.T., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Cape Town, South Africa
Abstract: Integrated resource plans have changed. While, in the past, nearly all generation technologies could be dispatched on demand, modern planners must incorporate intermittent renewable energy into their scenarios of the future energy mix. Based on forecasts of power and energy requirements and the costs of various technologies, selected scenarios test the trajectories of future prices and adequacy. The draft Integrated Resource Plan for South Africa published by the government in 2016, together with the diverse reactions to it, provide extensive material for analysis. Lessons include the need for careful identification of technical constraints, not simply basing a plan on the cost models; that forecasting the effects of the intermittency of solar and wind energy in South Africa is possible with available measured outputs; and that storage or curtailment of high renewable energy output when penetration levels increase are important. The analysis indicates the effects of intermittency on the cost models, and the significance of electricity supply industry structure and tariffs in supply planning. It appears bias in the planning group may affect the outcomes of integrated resource plans. The practical constraints in the plans advocating greater renew ables penetration could reduce system reliability, which means that decisions about the trajectory need to be taken now. The South African situation appears to be relevant for other developing and emerging economies. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Integrated resource plan; Levelised cost of energy; Load factor; Renewable energy
Index Keywords: Costs; Energy policy; Renewable energy resources; Resource allocation; Technological forecasting; Wind power; Generation technologies; Integrated resources; Levelised cost of energies; Load factors; Renewable energies; Scenarios of the future; Solar and wind energies; Technical constraints; Cost benefit analysis

Authors: Bamukunde J., Chowdhury S.
Title: A study on mitigation techniques for reduction and elimination of solar PV output fluctuations
Source title: 2017 IEEE AFRICON: Science, Technology and Innovation for Africa, AFRICON 2017
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, University of Cape Town, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Bamukunde, J., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Cape Town, South Africa; Chowdhury, S., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Cape Town, South Africa
Abstract: This paper reviews the power quality challenges associated with intermittency of grid connected PV systems and reviews energy storage systems and inverter control techniques that can be utilized to mitigate the fluctuations and power quality issues effectively. This review forms part of a future study which will incorporate a hybrid supercapacitor and battery energy storage system for ramp rate control, moving average control and virtual synchronous machine control respectively to eliminate and reduce the reviewed power quality challenges in grid connected PV systems. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Babatunde O.M., Munda J.L., Hamam Y.
Title: Hybrid energy system for low-income households
Source title: 2017 IEEE AFRICON: Science, Technology and Innovation for Africa, AFRICON 2017
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Tshwane University of Technology, Pretoria, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Babatunde, O.M., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Tshwane University of Technology, Pretoria, South Africa; Munda, J.L., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Tshwane University of Technology, Pretoria, South Africa; Hamam, Y., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Tshwane University of Technology, Pretoria, South Africa
Abstract: This paper presents an analysis of an off-grid hybrid energy system (HES) for a single residential apartment owned by a low-income earner. The system is made up of photovoltaic (PV), wind, battery storage system, and a gasoline generator. Using a house in Akoka, Nigeria as a case study, the HES is developed to adequately supply a load of 3.8kWh/day. The technical, economic and environmental considerations are presented. The results revealed the potential of the HES to provide environment-friendly, cost-effective and affordable electricity for the low income household, as compared to using only gasoline generators. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors with affiliations: Ribisi, E.T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University, Port Elizabeth, South Africa; Freere, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University, Port Elizabeth, South Africa
Abstract: When photovoltaic systems are used as the energy source to start motors, the resultant voltage drop can be too large to enable effective starting. An active filter circuit using inductor energy storage is described, which can be used to maintain the output voltage. Simulation and experimental results are shown. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Prapanukool C., Chaitusaney S.
Title: An appropriate battery capacity and operation schedule of battery energy storage system for PV Rooftop with net-metering scheme
Source title: ECTI-CON 2017 - 2017 14th International Conference on Electrical Engineering/Electronics, Computer, Telecommunications and Information Technology
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, 254 Phayathai Rd., Pathumwan Bangkok, 10330, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Prapanukool, C., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, 254 Phayathai Rd., Pathumwan Bangkok, 10330, Thailand; Chaitusaney, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, 254 Phayathai Rd., Pathumwan Bangkok, 10330, Thailand
Abstract: To mitigate impact from high penetration of PV Rooftop, Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) is implemented. One of the main customers who install the PV Rooftop is the residential load with TOU structure. Normally, there are many characteristics and types of BESS, depending on the application. To combine with PV Rooftop, Li-ion Battery is an appropriate type. Battery capacity, State of Charge, C-rate and lifetime are necessary factors that should be considered. The characteristics of BESS considerably affect the investment cost (IC) and O&M cost (OC) of BESS, especially battery capacity. The larger battery capacity the higher IC and OC. However, the larger battery capacity will reduce more electricity charge (EC) of the customers, which is the most attractive benefit of BESS, particularly when the Net-Metering Scheme is applicable. Therefore, an appropriate battery capacity and operation schedule of BESS for PV Rooftop is investigated in this paper by using Genetic Algorithm. The proposed battery capacity and operation schedule will minimize the electricity charge of the costumers as much as possible with the lowest investment cost and O&M cost of the BESS. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery Capacity; Battery Energy Storage System (BESS); Electricity Charge; Net-Metering Scheme; Operation Schedule; PV Rooftop

Authors: Mamen A., Supatti U.
Title: A survey of hybrid energy storage systems applied for intermittent renewable energy systems
Source title: ECTI-CON 2017 - 2017 14th International Conference on Electrical Engineering/Electronics, Computer, Telecommunications and Information Technology
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering at Sriracha, Kasetsart University, Sriracha Campus, Chonburi, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Mamen, A., Faculty of Engineering at Sriracha, Kasetsart University, Sriracha Campus, Chonburi, Thailand; Supatti, U., Faculty of Engineering at Sriracha, Kasetsart University, Sriracha Campus, Chonburi, Thailand
Abstract: Hybrid Energy Storage Systems (HESS) draws more attention to electrical power generation systems from renewable energy resources as they can solve problems of fluctuated power created by intermittent energy sources (PV/Wind/Wave). Moreover, the HESS can minimize and smoothen out demand and supply mismatch of energy. This paper is a survey of the HESS applied for renewable energy sources. The structure of HESS based on combining of electrical storage devices and electrochemical energy storage is comparatively studied. The evaluation on capital cost, power rating and characteristic of storage devices results in an optimum combination of the Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) with battery and Super Capacitor (SC) with battery. The mixture of the SMES with battery is appropriate for power generation system with high power penetration, such as wind power generation. However, the combination of SC with battery is suitable for the lower power penetration system such as a solar PV generation system. © 2017 IEEE.

Abstract: The objective of this experimental research is to examine the effects of variable operating speeds and capacitance on the terminal voltage and frequency of a stand-alone self-excited induction generator (SEIG)-based flywheel energy storage system (FESS). The experiments were carried out under the no-load and on-load conditions using the SEIG-based FESS prototype, given the variable operating speeds and capacitance. The experimental results are graphically presented and compared. More importantly, the experimental findings are to be further applied to the design of an optimal control scheme for the flywheel energy storage system in our subsequent research. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Nguyen A.T., Chaitusaney S.
Title: Optimum schedule and size of BESS in the low voltage network with high penetration of solar rooftops to maintain voltages within acceptable limit
Source title: ECTI-CON 2017 - 2017 14th International Conference on Electrical Engineering/Electronics, Computer, Telecommunications and Information Technology
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, A.T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Chaitusaney, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand
Abstract: Thanks to incentive policies for the development of solar generation technologies, the world has recorded such an expensive generation technology largely deployed in daily life. It is expected a similar prospect to battery energy storage system (BESS) which is a multi-benefit solution with high penetration of renewable energy in general and solar rooftops in particular. In low voltage networks with high penetration of solar rooftops, voltages may rise dramatically. Standing on the utility view point, this paper investigates the minimum cost and size of BESS which is needed to help maintain voltages to be within the acceptable limits. Based on perfect day-ahead forecast of generation and load, optimum schedule of the BESS is obtained. In addition, this paper also considers the aging degradation of BESS. Using Matlab 2015b, the proposed method is simulated in a simplified network of Metropolitan Electricity Authority (MEA), Thailand [1] for the peak day with time interval of one hour. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Sok V., Tayjasanant T.
Title: Determination of optimal siting and sizing of energy storage system in PV-connected distribution systems considering minimum energy losses
Source title: ECTI-CON 2017 - 2017 14th International Conference on Electrical Engineering/Electronics, Computer, Telecommunications and Information Technology
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Sok, V., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand; Tayjasanant, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand
Abstract: This paper proposes a technique using Energy Storage (ES) system to reduce power losses in distribution system where Photovoltaic (PV) is connected with grid, and mitigate voltage rise and voltage drop simultaneously. The sensitivity analysis of system loss is used to define the location of ES with the minimum energy losses. A modified IEEE 34-bus test system was simulated by Matlab/Simulink. Simulation results show that optimal siting and sizing of ES can help keeping voltages within the range and also minimizing energy losses. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Pathomchaiwat P., Neammanee B.
Title: Control of power management in the renewable energy system by using Flywheel Energy Storage
Source title: ECTI-CON 2017 - 2017 14th International Conference on Electrical Engineering/Electronics, Computer, Telecommunications and Information Technology
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok, Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Pathomchaiwat, P., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok, Bangkok, Thailand; Neammanee, B., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok, Bangkok, Thailand
Abstract: This paper presents a control technique of power management in the stand alone hybrid system by using Flywheel Energy Storage (FES). FES helps the system to regulate the load power, when the generated energy from renewable source has less than consumed energy. FES supplies the insufficient energy to the load power while the generated energy source has greater than the load power; the excess energy is stored in FES. This paper models the stand alone hybrid system between diesel generator, wind turbine generator and FES. The FES which composed of flywheel coupled to squirrel cage induction machine (SCIM) is controlled by machine side converter (MSC). The MSC model based on the rotor flux oriented vector control to regulate the DC bus voltage under constrain of energy charge or discharge stage of FES. The model which are simulated to show the FES can improve the dynamic performance of the hybrid system in many case such as wind energy fluctuation, slow response of diesel engine and load fluctuation by charge and discharge the energy from the flywheel according to the control objectives. © 2017 IEEE.

Abstract: In this paper, we propose an ultra-low-voltage (ULV) SRAM in 28nm FDSOI based on a 7-T ULP bitcell that allows using only low Vt (LVT) transistors for density and speed without prohibitive leakage. The retention is based on two CMOS negative-differential resistance (NDR) structures. Thanks to importance sampling (IS) methodology, the proposed bitcell has been sized to reach low failure rate for 8-kB macro. Process voltage temperature (PVT) compensation is performed on-chip by an adaptive back biasing (ABB) generator. At 0.4V, the proposed SRAM can operate at 80 MHz and reaches access energy of 28 fJ/bit including the ABB generator in closed-loop operation. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Importance sampling; SRAM; Ultra-low power; Ultra-low power diodes; Ultra-low voltage

Abstract: The proceedings contain 74 papers. The topics discussed include: hydrogen energy storage based green power plant in seashore of Bangladesh: design and optimal cost analysis; simultaneous placement of multi-dg and capacitor in distribution system using hybrid optimization method; an enhancement on class diagram to model a secure context aware system; implementing a next generation system to provide protection to vehicles from thefts and accidents; life cycle cost analysis of solar-led alternatives to fuel-based fishing net indicator; certain investigations on water treatment processes for healthy life-review; ripple current and power loss analysis for 2l and 3l 1500v DC grid tied inverter through PLECS modeling; development of assistive application for patients with communication disability; classification of sleep disorders based on EEG signals by using feature extraction techniques with KNN classifier; immunize - baby steps for smart healthcare; a LS-compression scheme for grayscale images using pixel based technique; frozen shoulder rehabilitation using Microsoft Kinect; optimal allocation and sizing of dg in a radial distribution system using whale optimization algorithm; and efficiency enhancement of thermal power plants using refrigerant-r600a in condenser section.

Authors: Zhang Z., Lei Z., En Y., Liu J.
Title: Monte-Carlo prediction of single-event characteristics of 65 nm CMOS SRAM under hundreds of MeV/n heavy-ions in space
Source title: Proceedings of the European Conference on Radiation and its Effects on Components and Systems, RADECS
Affiliations: Science and Technology on Reliability Physics and Application of Electronic Component Laboratory, China Electronic Product Reliability and Environmental Testing Research Institute, Guangzhou, 510610, China; Institute of Modern Physics, Chinese Academy of Science, Lanzhou, 730000, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Z., Science and Technology on Reliability Physics and Application of Electronic Component Laboratory, China Electronic Product Reliability and Environmental Testing Research Institute, Guangzhou, 510610, China; Lei, Z., Science and Technology on Reliability Physics and Application of Electronic Component Laboratory, China Electronic Product Reliability and Environmental Testing Research Institute, Guangzhou, 510610, China; En, Y., Science and Technology on Reliability Physics and Application of Electronic Component Laboratory, China Electronic Product Reliability and Environmental Testing Research Institute, Guangzhou, 510610, China; Liu, J., Institute of Modern Physics, Chinese Academy of Science, Lanzhou, 730000, China
Abstract: Single-event performance of 65 nm CMOS SRAM technology was revealed by Monte-Carlo methods, with heavy ions energy ranging from 20 MeV/n to 2 GeV/n. By comparing the energy-deposition spectrums in sensitive volumes (SV) and single event upset (SEU) cross sections, it was found that secondary electrons and nuclear reactions of the 200 MeV/n incident ions have significant impact on the device response. Secondary electrons excited by the energetic space ions can spread beyond the SV of the 65 nm bulk CMOS SRAM and result into partial collection of the ion track. This mechanism causes the constant increase of SEU cross section with ion LET, even deviating from the surface area of the SV by 3.3×. Nuclear reaction can lead to unexpectedly large energy-deposition events in the SV by 10x than the initial LET, which create SEU cross sections in the sub-LETth region, although with lower probability than direct-ionization process by 104×∼105×. Higher ion energy seems to enhance the influence of secondary electrons and nuclear reaction. Moreover, soft error rates of the 65 nm bulk CMOS SRAM technology on GEO were predicted and discussed. © 2016 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Monte-Carlo; nuclear reaction; secondary electron; single event upset; static random access memory

Abstract: In this summary, the resistive random access memory (RRAM) with the structure of Pt/HfO2/Ti is investigated for applications in radiation circumstance. The heavy ion 86Kr26+ of HIRFL (The Heavy Ion Research Facility in Lanzhou) is used as the radiation source. The energy of 86Kr26+ is 25 MeV/u, the LET is 37.6 MeV/(cm2/mg), and the fluence of 5e11 is achieved after 2 hours radiation. Basic performance of the Pt/HfO2/Ti is compared before and after radiation. An obvious decrease is shown in the original resistance value after radiation, and the forming process is no longer needed. The HRS, LRS, transition voltage and endurance are still stable after radiation. © 2016 IEEE.

Authors: Huang M., Fu L., Zhang Y., Gao X.
Title: Optimal design of an island microgrid with considering scheduling optimization
Source title: 2017 International Smart Cities Conference, ISC2 2017
Affiliations: National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval University of Engineering, Wuhan, China
Authors with affiliations: Huang, M., National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval University of Engineering, Wuhan, China; Fu, L., National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval University of Engineering, Wuhan, China; Zhang, Y., National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval University of Engineering, Wuhan, China; Gao, X., National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval University of Engineering, Wuhan, China
Abstract: Stand-Alone microgrid system consist of hybrid wind/PV/diesel/storage is one of the effective approaches to solve the problem for future island power supply while plan and design are one of the core technical systems of it. According to operation requirements of the island stand-Alone microgrid and the characteristics of distributed power supply as well as the optimization demand of microgrid capacity, an optimized scheduling model for microgrid that consider the initial investment cost, maintenance and replacement cost, fuel cost, environmental management cost, and power shortage penalty cost is proposed in this paper. The constraint of the utilization rate of renewable energy, single and total loss of power supply probability (LPSP), single and total dumped energy proportion (DEP) are also under consideration. Through the establishment of the mixed integer linear programming model (MILP), the integrated modeling and solving of the stand-Alone microgrid planning and optimization scheduling problem are realized. The effectiveness of the designed model is verified through the result of some island microgrid. Furthermore, the impact of the reliability constraint of the system power supply and the penalty factor of the dumped wind/PV energy is analyzed. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: capacity allocation; distributed generation; mixed integer linear programming; stand-Alone microgrid
Index Keywords: Costs; Distributed power generation; Environmental management; Investments; Scheduling; Smart city; Capacity allocation; Distributed power supplies; Micro grid; Mixed integer linear programming; Mixed integer linear programming model; Optimization scheduling; Reliability constraints; Scheduling optimization; Integer programming

Authors: Keles C., Alagoz B.B., Kaygusuz A.
Title: Multi-source energy mixing for renewable energy microgrids by particle swarm optimization
Source title: IDAP 2017 - International Artificial Intelligence and Data Processing Symposium
Affiliations: Department of Electrical-Electronics Engineering, Inonu University, Malatya, Turkey; Department of Computer Engineering, Inonu University, Malatya, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Keles, C., Department of Electrical-Electronics Engineering, Inonu University, Malatya, Turkey; Alagoz, B.B., Department of Computer Engineering, Inonu University, Malatya, Turkey; Kaygusuz, A., Department of Electrical-Electronics Engineering, Inonu University, Malatya, Turkey
Abstract: Distributed intelligence is one of the prominent prospects of future smart grids besides distributed generation, distributed storage and demand side load management. This study illustrates utilization of particle swarm optimization (PSO) method for cost-efficient energy management in multi-source renewable energy microgrids. PSO algorithm is used to find out optimal energy mixing rates that can minimize daily energy cost of a renewable microgrids under energy balance and anti-islanding constraints. The optimal energy mixing rates can be used by multi-pulse width modulation (M-PWM) energy mixer units. In our numerical analyses, we consider a multi-source renewable energy grid scenario that includes solar energy system, wind energy system, battery system and utility grid connection. We assume that variable energy pricing is used in utility grid to control energy dispatches between microgrids. This numerical analysis shows that the proposed scheme can adjust energy mixing rates for M-PWM energy mixers to achieve the cost-efficient and energy balanced management of microgrid under varying generation, demand and price conditions. The proposed method illustrates an implementation of distributed intelligence in smart grids. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Cost efficient energy mixing; Intelligent systems; Microgrid; Particle swarm optimization; Smart grid

Authors: Batawy S.A.E., Gray M.K., Morsi W.G.
Title: Multi-objective optimization of energy storage and wind DGs for self-adequacy of microgrid equipped with fast DC charging station
Source title: 2017 IEEE Power and Energy Society Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference, ISGT 2017
Authors with affiliations: Batawy, S.A.E.; Gray, M.K.; Morsi, W.G.
Abstract: This paper presents a framework to determine the optimal siting and sizing of Wind-based distributed generators (WDGs) and energy storage systems (ESSs) in a micro-grid (MG), considering the total active power losses in the system, the self-adequacy index (SAI), and the total annual cost (TAC) of the WDGs and the ESSs. The work in this paper employs multi-objective optimization (MOO) based on archived multi-objective simulated annealing in order to obtain a diverse set of Pareto optimal solutions. The analysis formulates the siting and sizing optimization problem considering a MG with a Fast Direct Current Charging Station (FDCCS). The results of the simulation have revealed that the optimal solution results in a trade-off between increasing SAI and increased TAC. Finally, it was seen that the optimal siting and sizing of the WDGs are highly affected by the location of the FDCCS. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Distributed generators; Fast DC charging station; Multi-objective optimization; Self-Adequacy
Index Keywords: Distributed power generation; Economic and social effects; Electric power transmission networks; Energy storage; Optimal systems; Optimization; Pareto principle; Simulated annealing; Smart power grids; Active power loss; Charging station; Distributed generators; Energy Storage Systems (ESSs); Optimal solutions; Pareto optimal solutions; Self-Adequacy; Siting and sizings; Multiobjective optimization

Authors: Biyya I., Aniba G., Maaroufi M.
Title: Impact of load and renewable energy uncertainties on single and multiple energy storage systems sizing
Source title: 2017 IEEE Power and Energy Society Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference, ISGT 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Ecole Mohammadia d'Ingénieurs, Mohammed v University of Rabat, Rabat, Morocco
Authors with affiliations: Biyya, I., Department of Electrical Engineering, Ecole Mohammadia d'Ingénieurs, Mohammed v University of Rabat, Rabat, Morocco; Aniba, G., Department of Electrical Engineering, Ecole Mohammadia d'Ingénieurs, Mohammed v University of Rabat, Rabat, Morocco; Maaroufi, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Ecole Mohammadia d'Ingénieurs, Mohammed v University of Rabat, Rabat, Morocco
Abstract: This paper questions the impact of Renewable Energy Sources and load uncertainties on sizing Energy Storage Systems, as well as these uncertainties dynamics in a distributed configuration. Given the current energetic concern, the importance of the massive integration of renewable energies and storage systems, in number and kind, has become obvious. Nonetheless, demand matching with these two options is quite challenging inasmuch as renewable energy sources are significantly random and as storage systems are high-priced and imitate load and production uncertainties. For this purpose, herein we firstly used Gaussian Mixtures to model renewable energy outcome; secondly, we developed a probabilistic procedure to size Energy Storage Systems as an aggregated unit, and finally, we examined the impact of distributing generation on uncertainties of individual units. Simulations on real load and photovoltaic historical data show that uncertainties, with respect to rating power and energy, slightly increase in a non-linear fashion. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Distributed Generation; Energy Storage System (EE)S; High penetration; Probabilistic Sizing; Renewable Energy Sources (RES)

Authors: Liu K., Sheng W., Chen D., Du S., Ye H., Su J., Zhang Y.
Title: Research on multi-CPU cluster modeling and real-time simulation analysis of high proportion active distribution network
Source title: 2017 3rd IEEE International Conference on Control Science and Systems Engineering, ICCSSE 2017
Affiliations: China Electric Power Research Institute, Beijing, China; China Agricultural University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, K., China Electric Power Research Institute, Beijing, China; Sheng, W., China Electric Power Research Institute, Beijing, China; Chen, D., China Agricultural University, Beijing, China; Du, S., China Agricultural University, Beijing, China; Ye, H., China Agricultural University, Beijing, China; Su, J., China Agricultural University, Beijing, China; Zhang, Y., China Agricultural University, Beijing, China
Abstract: High proportion of renewable energy was increased in the distribution network, which will face complex grid complex test and show the scale the diversity and complexity of the operating state. So that the evolution of Wind-photovoltaic-energy storage(Wind-PV-ES) hybrid network transient process is not clear. In the other hand, Transient simulation tool plays a significant role in obtaining a full and detailed response under various operation conditions. However, the simulation capability and speed become limited with increased system size. In order to study the background of high proportion of Wind-PV-ES in the distribution network, this paper model Wind-PV-ES and its control system in the multi-CPU cluster fine-grained real-time simulation platform. The control system was further decoupled according to its topology. The multi-CPU can be easily realized, and the computation loads are balanced by DG modeling. The model is used to calculate the load balancing as the optimal condition to be decoupled by the distribution parameters. Parallel computing to ensure the accuracy of the transient simulation results and convergence effect and improve the simulation speed. Then this paper used two typical examples to realize the verification of Multi-CPU simulation results. The simulation results show that the simulation accuracy decreases with the increase of model computation, but the simulation speed is greatly improved. The result reflects the characteristics and transient characteristics of grid -connected transient operation. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated in integrated simulation of distributed generation system. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: distributed parameter decoupled model; multi-CPU cluster calculate; real-time simulation; transient grid process; wind-photovoltaic-batter storage modeling
Index Keywords: Control systems; Systems engineering; Active distribution networks; Decoupled model; Distributed generation system; multi-CPU cluster calculate; Photovoltaic; Real time simulation platform; Real time simulations; Transient characteristic; Complex networks

Title: Research on flexible self starting strategy of wind storage isolated network system
Source title: 2017 3rd IEEE International Conference on Control Science and Systems Engineering, ICCSSE 2017
