Abstract: The proceedings contain 39 papers. The topics discussed include: on understanding time, energy and cost performance of wimpy heterogeneous systems for edge computing; a-priori estimation of computation times in fog networked robotics; MECCAS: collaborative storage algorithm based on alternating direction method of multipliers on mobile edge cloud; zenith: utility-aware resource allocation for edge computing; designing distributed applications using a phase-aware, reversible system; comparing pacemaker with OpenSAF for availability management in the cloud; and on forecasting Amazon EC2 Spot prices using time-series decomposition with hybrid look-backs.

Authors: Cai H., Ji X., Wei W.
Title: Decentralized autonomous operation for islanded photovoltaic-based DC microgrids
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China
Authors with affiliations: Cai, H., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Ji, X., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Wei, W., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China
Abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized autonomous control strategy to operate an islanded photovoltaic-based DC micro-grid (IPDMG) without any communication networks. The presented control strategy considers the limited capacity of the energy storage system (ESS) and makes the PV sources autonomously switch from maximum power point trakcing (MPPT) mode into voltage control mode to regulate the DC-bus voltage and share their output powers in a cooperative way whenever necessary. In voltage control mode, PV sources shift in accordance with load demands while regulating the DC-bus voltage, which avoids large ESS reserve in the IPDMG and further improves the PV penetration. Simulation results on Matlab/Simulink are presented to validate the proposed control strategy. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: Autonomous operation; Decentralized Control; Islanded photovoltaic-based DC micrgorids

Authors: Zhou X., Fan Z., Ma Y., Gao Z.
Title: Research review on electrical energy storage technology
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, X., Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China; Fan, Z., Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China; Ma, Y., Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China; Gao, Z., Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China
Abstract: This paper introduces the electrical energy storage technology. Firstly, it briefly expounds the significance and value of electrical energy storage technology research, analyzes the role of electrical energy storage technology, and briefly introducts electrical energy storage technology, it focuses on the research status of energy storage technology in micro grid, distributed generation, new energy power generation, smart grid, energy Internet and electric vehicle. Finally, considering the characteristics and requirements of the micro grid, distributed generation, new energy power generation, smart grid, energy Internet and electric vehicles, both some existing problems and the future development trend of electrical energy storage technology are presented. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: distributed generation; electric vehicles; Electrical energy storage technology; energy internet; micro grid; new energy power generation; smart grid

Authors: Li P., Wang G., Zhang X., Ma M.
Title: Optimal design of a high-power friction brake based on improved genetic algorithm
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval Univ. of Engineering, Wuhan, 430033, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, P., National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval Univ. of Engineering, Wuhan, 430033, China; Wang, G., National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval Univ. of Engineering, Wuhan, 430033, China; Zhang, X., National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval Univ. of Engineering, Wuhan, 430033, China; Ma, M., National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Vessel Integrated Power System, Naval Univ. of Engineering, Wuhan, 430033, China
Abstract: For the emergency braking of a large-capacity inertia flywheel energy storage system, this paper refers to a rapid braking scheme based on the friction brake. However, its difficulty lies in the design of a high power brake, which includes temperature, volume, power and so on. The present multi-objective optimization algorithm is not available for engineers due to its complicated design, much difficulty in implementation, and time-consuming calculation. Therefore, this paper has proposed an improved genetic algorithm to solve multiple constraints, which can be changed into a problem of common constraint. Moreover the algorithm is convenient for designers because of its ideal convergence, universality and flexibility. The prototype testing proves the braking scheme of the large-capacity flywheel energy storage system to be feasible and the optimized algorithm for the friction brake to be effective, which can play a certain guiding role in engineering practice. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: friction brake; genetic algorithm; multi-objective optimization; penalty function

Authors: Li Q., Zou J., Li L.
Title: Optimum operation on electric vehicles considering battery degradation in V2G system
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: School of Automation Engineering, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, Sichuan, 611731, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Q., School of Automation Engineering, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, Sichuan, 611731, China; Zou, J., School of Automation Engineering, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, Sichuan, 611731, China; Li, L., School of Automation Engineering, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, Sichuan, 611731, China
Abstract: In vehicle-to-grid system (V2G), a great number of electric vehicles (EVs) can form a massive energy storage to perform the operation of charging, discharging and providing frequency regulation for the grid. This process may lead to battery degradation of the EVs. In this paper, we propose to optimize the operation of EVs in each hour to maximize the user's total revenue, where Lithium battery is used for the EVs and the battery degradation is considered. Here, battery degradation includes two parts, one is the degradation caused by battery temperature during EVs' charging and discharging; another is the degradation caused by the depth of discharge (DoD). Considering the real-time electricity price, the optimum operation of each hour, i.e., charging, discharging or frequency regulation, can be obtained by V2G control center. Simulation results are provided to demonstrate that an optimum operation in each hour can be obtained to maximize the users profit. It also shows that large charging or discharging rate, and DoD reduces the battery's capacity and life cycle, which finally leads to the loss of user's benefit. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: Battery degradation; electric vehicles (EVs); frequency regulation; Lithium battery; optimum operation; vehicle-to-grid system (V2G)

Authors: Gao M., Du C., Chen J., Chen A., Zhang C.
Title: A virtual impedance based coordinated control strategy for distributed supercapacitors in DC microgrid
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong, 250061, China
Authors with affiliations: Gao, M., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong, 250061, China; Du, C., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong, 250061, China; Chen, J., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong, 250061, China; Chen, A., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong, 250061, China; Zhang, C., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong, 250061, China
Abstract: Supercapacitors (SCs) are widely utilized as energy storage units (ESUs) to compensate the transient power fluctuations. In this paper, an improved virtual impedance based coordinated control strategy for distributed SCs is proposed to achieve accurate power distribution. Unlike the existed strategy which can hardly adjust the output power of each SC if the energy storage system contains several distributed SCs, the proposed control scheme can allocate the output power of each SC according to the state-of-charge (SOC) without causing current oscillations. The power distribution among each SC is realized based on low-bandwidth-communication (LBC). And power distribution coefficients which are proportional to the SOC of each SC are introduced. By appropriate tuning the coefficients, the accurate power distribution of SCs is achieved. This method can not only supply energy instantly under transient conditions caused by loads or sources, but also realize precise power distribution between SCs. Meanwhile, this coordinated control strategy which has improved reliability is simple to implement, since it only uses local controllers and LBC network to exchange information between SCs. The effectiveness of the proposed control strategy is verified by simulation results. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: DC microgrid; low-bandwidth-communication (LBC); power distribution; Supercapacitor (SC); virtual impedance

Authors: Wei X., Li K., Zhang C., Yan Y., Sun Y.
Title: Operation strategy and economic analysis of biogas CCHP system including compressed air energy storage
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China
Authors with affiliations: Wei, X., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China; Li, K., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China; Zhang, C., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China; Yan, Y., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China; Sun, Y., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China
Abstract: Combined cooling heating and power (CCHP) system in which biogas internal combustion engine (ICE) as the prime mover is a valid way to solve energy crisis and environmental pollution, energy storage device accessing grid become feasible due to the time-of-use (TOU) power price policy. A combined system coupling biogas ICE with compressed air energy storage (CAES) is proposed and the study of different operation modes is conducted. Economic analysis is done on the basis of models of different energy-supply systems. Results demonstrate the proposed system has great economic advantages, the ICE capacity is reduced and power generating efficiency is improved due to the CAES. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: Biogas combined cooling heating and power; compressed air energy storage; economic analysis; operation strategy

Authors: Kong Z., Cui N., Li P.
Title: Energy management strategy coordinating lithium-ion battery and ultra-capacitor for electric vehicle
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China
Authors with affiliations: Kong, Z., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China; Cui, N., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China; Li, P., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China
Abstract: A real-time energy optimization management for electric vehicles with hybrid energy storage system (HESS) is presented in this paper. The HESS is combined with lithium-ion battery and ultra-capacitor. Based on the quadratic optimization strategy, the power relationship of hybrid energy storage system and the battery power loss characteristics is analyzed. A quadratic performance index is established to minimize the power loss of the battery under the condition of meeting the desired vehicle velocity demand. The joint simulation results show that the allocation of power is optimized, and the lithium-ion battery workload is reduced, as well as lithium-ion battery power loss. Meanwhile, the research is of great significance to improve the dynamic performance of electric vehicles and extend the driving range. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: electric vehicle (EV); energy management strategy (EMS); hybrid energy storage system (HESS)

Authors: Ma Y., Yang P., Zhou X., Gao Z.
Title: Energy storage capacity optimization research for micro grid including electricity and heat
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China
Authors with affiliations: Ma, Y., Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China; Yang, P., Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China; Zhou, X., Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China; Gao, Z., Key Research Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, 300384, China
Abstract: Because of the randomness and volatility of renewable energy generation and load, energy storage device plays an important role in ensuring the safe and steady operation of micro grid. For a combined heat and power micro grid, Heat tank is modeled similar to battery and allocation model of heat and electricity storage based on economic dispatch is established. Multi-scenario theory is adopted to consider randomness and artificial bee colony is applied to optimize the operation of micro grid with different storage capacity. Finally, composite cost of micro grid with different storage capacity is compared to determine the best capacity. A case study is conducted to verify that method and model presented can effectively decrease composite cost. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: artificial bee colony(ABC); composite cost; energy storage capacity optimization; micro grid; multi-scenario theory

Authors: Liu J., Zheng Z.
Title: Distributed cooperative current-sharing control of coupled parallel charging systems with super-capacitor loads
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: School of Mathematics and Statistics, Hunan University of Commerce, Changsha, 410205, China; School of Mechatronics Engineering and Automation, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, J., School of Mathematics and Statistics, Hunan University of Commerce, Changsha, 410205, China, School of Mechatronics Engineering and Automation, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Zheng, Z., School of Mechatronics Engineering and Automation, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China
Abstract: In order to address the output current imbalanced problem of parallel chargers for energy storage type light rail vehicles, a distributed cooperative current-sharing scheme is proposed in this paper. Considering each charger as an agent, the current-sharing control design can be modeled as the output current consensus-tracking problem of nonlinear and non-identical multi-agent systems with the bounded control input. The communication topology between each parallel charger is modeled a directed graph, which only needs a spanning tree. In order to guarantee the boundedness of the control input, a general saturation function is introduced into the control law. One distributed cooperative PID current-sharing controller is designed based on the nearest neighborhood rule. The system stability and dynamic performance of the proposed cooperative control scheme is evaluated by analyzing the transfer function matrix from the input duty ratio to the output current. When the physical parameters and communication topology of the parallel chargers are given in advance, the system stability can be maintained by choosing the proportional, integral and derivative control gains. The output current of parallel chargers can be balanced by adopting the proposed approach, which is verified by simulating a parallel charging test system. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: Cooperative PID Control; Current-Sharing Control; Multi-Agent Systems; Parallel Chargers

Authors: Li Q., Wang L., Wang G., Zhang B.
Title: Low-carbon configuration optimization for multi-energy complementary microgrid
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Q., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China; Wang, L., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China; Wang, G., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China; Zhang, B., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250061, China
Abstract: In order to reduce carbon emissions in the lifecycle of multi-energy complementary microgrids, this work proposes a low-carbon configuration optimization model based on the characteristics of carbon emissions in the operation of microgrids and renewable energy utilization in the configuration process. Also, genetic algorithm is adopted to solve the configuration problem of microgrids. Simulation results demonstrate that the capacity of renewable energy and energy storage is enhanced with the increase of carbon taxes. Although higher initial investment and recovery period might be caused by carbon taxes, environmental and economic benefits in the lifecycle of microgrids are improved significantly. As a result, the validity and effectiveness of the proposed low-carbon configuration optimization approach are confirmed. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: Configuration; Low-carbon; Microgrid; Optimization

Authors: Ding S., Zhou X., Guo Q.
Title: Distributed optimization of energy storage units in non-ideal communication network
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: Institute of Automation, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Nanjing, 210023, China; Tong da Institute, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, YangZhou, 210003, China
Authors with affiliations: Ding, S., Institute of Automation, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Nanjing, 210023, China; Zhou, X., Tong da Institute, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, YangZhou, 210003, China; Guo, Q., Institute of Automation, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Nanjing, 210023, China
Abstract: Energy storage systems (ESSs) usually are used to keep active power and frequency stable in the microgrid, especially in the autonomous microgrid. Some factors often happen just like time-varying topology and channel noise in actual communication network. This paper uses multi-agent system and every agent represents an energy storage unit. This paper chooses the battery energy storage system (BESS). Distributed gradient algorithm is used to control the active powers of ESSs. In this paper, simulation is carried out in non-ideal communication network and simulation results before and after suppressing noise are compared. The simulation results show that distributed gradient algorithm can suppress the noise obviously. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: distributed gradient algorithm; energy storage unit; suppress channel noise; time-varying topology

Authors: Wu X., Sun Y., Wei Z., Sun G.
Title: Transmission losses power compensation in a microgrid based on distributed consensus algorithm
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: College of Energy and Electrical Engineering, Hohai University, Nanjing, 210098, China
Authors with affiliations: Wu, X., College of Energy and Electrical Engineering, Hohai University, Nanjing, 210098, China; Sun, Y., College of Energy and Electrical Engineering, Hohai University, Nanjing, 210098, China; Wei, Z., College of Energy and Electrical Engineering, Hohai University, Nanjing, 210098, China; Sun, G., College of Energy and Electrical Engineering, Hohai University, Nanjing, 210098, China
Abstract: In this paper, the distributed consensus algorithm is proposed to solve the power compensation problem of transmission losses with energy storage systems in a microgrid. Due to the transmission losses, the total power between electrical machines and loads may be not balanceable, the redundant or absent power must be used to charge or discharge the energy storage systems, which is vital to ensure the supply-demand balance in power grids. This paper proposes a distributed consensus algorithm for coordinating the energy storage systems to maintain the supply-demand balance, besides, the energy storage systems must be satisfied the relevant constrain conditions. Finally, simulation results based on the IEEE 5-bus system are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: Distributed consensus algorithm; Energy storage systems; Supply-demand balance; Transmission losses

Authors: Hao Z., Qiuxuan W., Xiaoni C., Weijie L., Yanbin L.
Title: Research on optimization scheduling of wind/solar/diesel/storage micro-grid based on genetic algorithm
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: Institute of Automation, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China; School of Youngman Automotive, Hangzhou Vocational and Technological School, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Hao, Z., Institute of Automation, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China; Qiuxuan, W., Institute of Automation, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China; Xiaoni, C., School of Youngman Automotive, Hangzhou Vocational and Technological School, Hangzhou, China; Weijie, L., Institute of Automation, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China; Yanbin, L., Institute of Automation, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China
Abstract: In this paper, we focus on the objective function of the economic cost and environment cost of wind/solar/diesel/storage micro-grids, and use the method of linear-weighting to establish the optimal scheduling mode of union objective. On the basis of making full use of renewable energy, the genetic algorithm is used to solve the problem of union objective, and created the operation plan of power grid, energy storage battery and diesel generator. The numerical examples show that under the condition of Island micro-grid system, unrestricted power of grid connection and limited power of grid connection, the optimal scheduling scheme can be obtained under different weights between economy and environment, and has actual reliability, and also plays a guiding role in the micro-grid optimal scheduling strategy. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: genetic algorithm; micro-grid; optimal scheduling; union objective

Authors: Liu B., Lin Q., Zheng T., Chen L., Mei S.
Title: Low carbon economic dispatch for multi-energy distribution network with compressed air energy storage system as energy hub
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; State Grid Wuhu Electric Power Company, Wuhu, Anhui Province, 241027, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, B., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Lin, Q., State Grid Wuhu Electric Power Company, Wuhu, Anhui Province, 241027, China; Zheng, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Chen, L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Mei, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Abstract: Nowadays, energy crisis and environmental pollution have made utilize multiple energy in an integrated way a trend of future energy system development. The multi-energy distribution network connected via energy hubs is one of the promising solutions. In this paper, an energy hub model of compressed air energy storage system is established for the integration in the multi-energy distribution network. Aiming at reducing the whole operation and carbon cost, a low carbon economic dispatch model for multi-energy distribution network is constructed and verified on a coupled system with a 13-bus power distribution network and a 13-node district heating network, which successfully demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed model in terms of reducing the total cost. This model can be generally extended to more complicated multi-energy networks. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: compressed air energy storage system; district heating network; energy hub; low carbon economic dispatch; Multi-energy distribution network; power distribution network

Authors: Lv X., Cheng X., Tian S., Fang C.
Title: Storage and parallel topology processing of the power network based on Neo4j
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, Shandong Province, 250022, China; Power Supply Company, Yantai, 264000, China
Authors with affiliations: Lv, X., School of Electrical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, Shandong Province, 250022, China; Cheng, X., School of Electrical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, Shandong Province, 250022, China; Tian, S., Power Supply Company, Yantai, 264000, China; Fang, C., School of Electrical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, Shandong Province, 250022, China
Abstract: With the rapid development of the information technology and the smart grid technology, the Energy Internet as the core of the third industrial revolution is on the rise. The EI is a complete set of future energy system from energy production, transportation, distribution, transformation and consumption and so on. The traditional model of data storage and processing have been unable to meet the requirements of high availability and real-time of the Energy Internet. In view of this, this paper proposes Graph-CIM model based on the Hadoop architecture, and build a service oriented architecture of processing the big data of the Energy Internet. This paper designs the interface based on the Graph-CIM model of the power network data management, and develops the application of power network topology processing. Finally, the data of the power network in Shandong is tested, which verifies the robustness of the distributed storage and the performance of parallel topology analysis. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: energy internet; Neo4j; power network topology processing; service oriented architecture

Authors: Zhang L., Xia X., Barzegar F.
Title: Control of a battery/supercapacitor hybrid energy storage system for electric vehicles
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, L., Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa; Xia, X., Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa; Barzegar, F., Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa
Abstract: This study looks into the power flow control of a battery/supercapacitor hybrid energy storage system when applied to electric vehicles. The controller is based on advanced model predictive control method and aims at smoothing the power flow from/to the battery to protect it from undesirable fast discharging/charging. The second objective of the controller is to control the electric vehicle to track a predefined speed profile. The dynamics of the vehicle and the supercapacitors are modeled from first principles to facilitate the controller design. It is assumed that the battery, as the primary energy source for the vehicle, is properly sized such that there is no need to control its state-of-charge. In addition, the controller is designed at the energy management level instead of power electronics control level. Therefore, it severs to optimize the power flows of the hybrid energy storage system instead of controlling the power converters involved. Simulations based on two commonly used urban driving cycles are carried out to verify the effectiveness of the design. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: Electric vehicle; hybrid energy storage system; model predictive control; power flow control; power source coordination

Authors: Jia L., Du C., Zhang C., Chen A.
Title: An ESU SoC balancing control method with output current ripple suppression ability in DC microgrid
Source title: Chinese Control Conference, CCC
Affiliations: School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, China
Authors with affiliations: Jia, L., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, China; Du, C., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, China; Zhang, C., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, China; Chen, A., School of Control Science and Engineering, Shandong University, China
Abstract: To balance the state-of-charge (SoC) of distributed energy storage units (ESUs) in dc microgrid, it is necessary to adjust the output power of each ESU according to its SoC, but the traditional SoC-based adaptive droop control methods can't adjust output power and suppress output ripple current simultaneously when there are several single-phase inverters connected to the dc bus. A SoC balancing method with output current ripple suppression ability is proposed in this paper. An adjustable virtual resistor is introduced through low pass filter (LPF) to adjust the output dc current to balance the SoC of ESUs, while a constant virtual inductor is introduced at twice fundamental frequency through band pass filter (BPF) to suppress output ripple current. Verification results are provided to validate the effectiveness and reasonability of the proposed control method. © 2017 Technical Committee on Control Theory, CAA.
Author Keywords: band pass filter; dc microgrid; distributed energy storage units; low pass filter; ripple current; State-of-charge

Authors: Zhang Z., Fu Y., Hu G.
Title: DualStack: A High Efficient Dynamic Page Scheduling Scheme in Hybrid Main Memory
Source title: 2017 IEEE International Conference on Networking, Architecture, and Storage, NAS 2017 - Proceedings
Affiliations: College of Command Information Systems, PLA University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Z., College of Command Information Systems, PLA University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China; Fu, Y., College of Command Information Systems, PLA University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China; Hu, G., College of Command Information Systems, PLA University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China
Abstract: With the development of big data and multi-core processors technology, DRAM-only based main memory cannot satisfy the requirements of in-memory computing in high memory capacity and low energy consumption. The emerging memory technology-phase change memory (PCM) is proposed to break the bottleneck of the current memory system. However, its weaknesses in write endurance and long access latency make it cannot fully replace DRAM. Consequently, researchers presented the architectural design aimed at DRAM/PCM hybrids and the corresponding page migration scheme to give full play to their merits. The urgent challenges facing by existed page migration schemes are poor performed under weak locality in data streams and further improvement need in prediction of future access tendency. In this paper, we propose an efficient page migration policy called DualStack which features dynamic page management according to global read and write information and temporal locality. It is designed to keep write-intensive pages to DRAM and read-intensive pages to PCM, and specially avoid frequent and unnecessary migration between hybrid memory media. Compared to the state-of-the-art of hybrid main memory, our experimental results indicate that DualStack can effectively improve the system I/O latency by 38%58% on the premise of reducing the system power consumption by 20%30%. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Big data; Digital storage; Energy utilization; Green computing; Memory architecture; Phase change memory; Emerging memory technologies; Hybrid main memory; Low energy consumption; Multi-core processor; Phase change memory (pcm); Scheduling schemes; State of the art; Temporal locality; Dynamic random access storage

Authors: Poonsuk J., Pongyupinpanich S.
Title: Design and estimation of state-charging applied for lithium-ion battery based on Matlab-Simulink
Source title: 2016 Management and Innovation Technology International Conference, MITiCON 2016
Affiliations: Computer Engineering Department Faculty of Engineering, Ramkhamhaeng University, Hua-Mark, Bangkapi, 10240, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Poonsuk, J., Computer Engineering Department Faculty of Engineering, Ramkhamhaeng University, Hua-Mark, Bangkapi, 10240, Thailand; Pongyupinpanich, S., Computer Engineering Department Faculty of Engineering, Ramkhamhaeng University, Hua-Mark, Bangkapi, 10240, Thailand
Abstract: For green technology applications, the lithium-ion battery is widely adopted as energy storage system due to high power and high energy density. However, there is a drawback on the storage system on charging interval time, particularly on electric vehicle applications. To accelerate, the multi-state current technique becomes a solution. In this paper, the state-charging of the lithium ion battery modeled by Matlab/Simulink is discussed. The state-of-charge (SOC) is measured and applied to evaluate the battery's charge/discharge characteristic. The multiple charging states applied for filling the battery capacity are evaluated in order to achieve high efficiency. In addition, the configurable three-state current design manipulated by a 8-bit microcontroller is introduced with a constant voltage at 20V and variable current from 5A to 60A. The investigation results are illustrated that, operating on Lithium-ion Ferro battery 12V 30Ah, the interval time of fill-up is reduced approximately 30% with working temperature 35° C. © 2016 IEEE.

Authors: Li F., Sun W., Yue S., Hu W.
Title: Trading storage for bandwidth - A simulation study of optical circuit switching with massive storage at network edge
Source title: International Conference on Transparent Optical Networks
Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Optical Communications Systems and Networks, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, F., State Key Laboratory of Advanced Optical Communications Systems and Networks, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China; Sun, W., State Key Laboratory of Advanced Optical Communications Systems and Networks, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China; Yue, S., State Key Laboratory of Advanced Optical Communications Systems and Networks, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China; Hu, W., State Key Laboratory of Advanced Optical Communications Systems and Networks, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China
Abstract: The network with massive storage at the switching nodes can store and forward bulk data from delay-insensitive applications. Increasing storage capacity can, under some circumstances, improve network throughput, like bandwidth does. In this paper, the effects of storage and bandwidth on OCS network performance and the principles of trading storage for bandwidth are discussed. Our research indicates that bandwidth is fair to flows with different sizes and is insensitive to different mean flow durations under the same load. On the contrary, the networks with massive storage are tend to discard larger flows and have favourable blocking rate to flows with smaller mean size. These results suggest that to achieve better performance in networks with mass storage, large flows should be split before transmitted to the network. Our research also suggests that the storage is particularly useful in handling bursty traffic. © 2017 IEEE.

Abstract: In this work, we investigate overlapping shared segment protection under continuous and TDM-mode sliding scheduled traffic model and compare its performance with that of shared path protection under sliding scheduled traffic model in Store-and-Transfer WDM Networks. Simulations show the following: Under continuous sliding scheduled traffic model, shared segment protection has 12% lower blocking rate than shared path protection and if number of requests is large, shared segment protection requires 20% more storage than share path protection. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Soares J., Sargento S.
Title: Re-optimizing the embedding of Virtual Infrastructures
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications
Affiliations: Portugal Telecom Inovação, Aveiro, Portugal; Instituto de Telecomunicações, University of Aveiro, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Soares, J., Portugal Telecom Inovação, Aveiro, Portugal; Sargento, S., Instituto de Telecomunicações, University of Aveiro, Portugal
Abstract: Today, in the cloud computing context, the network is starting to arise as a true resource itself and not just as a required connectivity add-on. The ability to define network resources (e.g. routing/switching elements, bandwidth) in this context is still scarce, but there are clear evidences that this is a future reality. In this article, we consider that cloud infrastructure services will allow the definition of complete infrastructures, to which we refer as Virtual Infrastructures (VIs). These VIs comprise computing, storage and network resources. This article specifically tackles the VI embedding problem, which is known to be NP-hard. Having in mind this fact, different embedding strategies based on Integer Linear Programming (ILP) formulation are presented. The problem is addressed by proposing strategies that target load balancing and energy consumption of physical resources along with re-optimization strategies. A thorough evaluation of the different strategies is performed, studying the VI acceptance ratio, physical infrastructure energy consumption, and the impact of reconfigurations. Results show that there is a clear tradeoff between improving the VI acceptance ratio and reducing the physical infrastructure usage without allowing re-optimizations. We study in-depth different ways of combined strategies. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Cloud Networking; Integer Linear Programming; Virtual Infrastructure; Virtualization
Index Keywords: Distributed computer systems; Energy utilization; Inductive logic programming (ILP); Optimization; Virtualization; Cloud infrastructures; Cloud networkings; Embedding problems; Embedding strategies; Integer Linear Programming; Optimization strategy; Physical resources; Virtual infrastructures; Integer programming

Authors: Soares J., Aparicio J., Sargento S.
Title: Dynamic strategies for the optimal embedding of virtual Infrastructures
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications
Affiliations: Portugal Telecom Inovação, Portugal; Instituto de Telecomunicações, University of Aveiro, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Soares, J., Portugal Telecom Inovação, Portugal; Aparicio, J., Instituto de Telecomunicações, University of Aveiro, Portugal; Sargento, S., Instituto de Telecomunicações, University of Aveiro, Portugal
Abstract: The offers on cloud computing infrastructure have focused on providing computing and storage resources, and consider the network mostly as a required add-on and not truly as a resource itself. However, the need to have more robust solutions is becoming clearer. This paper argues that cloud infrastructure services will evolve and allow the definition of complete infrastructures that comprise both computing and network resources, referred to as Virtual Infrastructures (VI). The VI embedding problem is addressed through joint virtualization of computing and network resources. An Integer Linear Programming (ILP) formulation is presented and different embedding strategies are proposed: load balancing, combining the load balancing of physical resources with minimal bandwidth consumption; green, reducing the energy consumption of the infrastructure; dynamic, combining both load balancing and green strategies depending on the substrate state. To enable real-time optimization, a heuristic approach is also proposed. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Cloud networking; Heuristic; Integer linear programming; Virtual infrastructure; Virtualization

Authors: Dvorsky E., Rakova L., Hejtmankova P.
Title: Grid frequency regulation by recycling electrical energy in flywheels
Source title: Proceedings of the 9th International Scientific Symposium on Electrical Power Engineering, ELEKTROENERGETIKA 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Power Engineering and Environmental Engineering, University of West Bohemia, Pilsen, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Dvorsky, E., Department of Electrical Power Engineering and Environmental Engineering, University of West Bohemia, Pilsen, Czech Republic; Rakova, L., Department of Electrical Power Engineering and Environmental Engineering, University of West Bohemia, Pilsen, Czech Republic; Hejtmankova, P., Department of Electrical Power Engineering and Environmental Engineering, University of West Bohemia, Pilsen, Czech Republic
Abstract: Grid frequency regulation function is based on the fact that the amount of power generated and the amount of power consumed must be in exact balance at all times. The system operator usually generates a signal which is called, Area Control Error (ACE), based on the difference between these two parameters. The expected goal is to keep the system near nominal frequency value. Traditionally, frequency regulation is managed by varying the output of power stations connected to the electric grid. The article presents a method in which electric energy, which is necessary for power balance keeping, is recycled, in the system. First, the system absorbs energy when it is in abundance, then discharges the same for the desired frequency regulation effect. The method is based on kinetic energy storage technology in high-speed flywheels (FES). The modeling results, based on actual ACE signals, should, indicate that a modular flywheel system can be effective in providing frequency regulation in power grids.
Author Keywords: Droop characteristics; Flywheels; Grid frequency regulation; Primary frequency control; Secondary frequency control
Index Keywords: Electric discharges; Flywheels; Kinetic energy; Kinetics; Recycling; Rotors; Wheels; Area control error; Droop characteristics; Electric energies; Electrical energy; Frequency regulations; Grid frequency; Nominal frequency; Primary frequency control; Electric power transmission networks

Authors: Zajaczek S., Cigánek J., Ďurica M.
Title: A new method of energy calculation through time integration of a vehicle momentary output using a model in matlab-simulink
Source title: Proceedings of the 9th International Scientific Symposium on Electrical Power Engineering, ELEKTROENERGETIKA 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, VŠB - TU Ostrava, Czech Republic

Abstract: Energy calculations in the electric traction are of a cardinal importance for a preliminary economic evaluation of passenger and material transport, with a possibility of an optimal configuration of a traction vehicle loading for a given track. Another field of the use is development and production of new traction vehicles where the electrical energy consumption during the run can be reduced through a modification of the aerodynamic shape or a change of a drive type while maintaining the output. The aim of our research is an optimization of a calculation of tramway vehicle electrical energy consumption through a design of a model of a simplified connection of a vehicle and a feed array in the Matlab - Simulink environment. The entry data of the vehicle speed and traction power are arranged in matrices in Workspace in Matlab and used for gradual reading up of the model entry parameters in the Simulink environment. After starting the simulation, the data of the model feed array current and voltage is stored according to a chosen time step in a form of matrices and is used for a later graphic display of the energy calculation or for a verification of the model with corresponding measured values.

Abstract: Today the sustainable energy is a hot scientific topic but if we examine the indicators of the world's energy we will find that globally is still dominated the fossil fuels so it is totally unsustainable furthermore there are also considerable problems of social and economic levels that are related to energy supply. In the 21. century one of the most important questions are global warming, CO2 emission and the security of energy supply. Renewable energy sources have an enormous potential, but their utilization is difficult due to their energy fluctuations and their stochastic - weather dependent - operation. We need a secondary energy sources that we can use as energy storage or we can use direct energy source. Of course, we consider it important to protect the environment and global access to energy sources. Maybe the hydrogen will be the future determinative energy source? In my paper, I analyze the current state of the hydrogen energy, future prospects, and I will introduce our research model and our research plan.

Title: Application of thermodiagnostics and numerical models in research of energy supply units using hydrogen technologies
Source title: Proceedings of the 9th International Scientific Symposium on Electrical Power Engineering, ELEKTROENERGETIKA 2017
Affiliations: Centre ENET, VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Ostrava, Czech Republic; Department of Electrical Power Engineering, VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Ostrava, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Moldrik, P., Centre ENET, VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Ostrava, Czech Republic; Minarik, D., Centre ENET, VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Ostrava, Czech Republic; Kacor, P., Department of Electrical Power Engineering, VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Ostrava, Czech Republic; Ney, M., Department of Electrical Power Engineering, VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Ostrava, Czech Republic
Abstract: This paper deals with utilisation of thermography for diagnostics of hydrogen fuel cells fitted with a proton exchange membrane, combined with photovoltaic panels to form a hybrid power system for storage of solar power into chemical energy in hydrogen with its subsequent conversion into electric power. Measurements taken using a thermal camera are used to identify distribution of the heat field over the stack of hydrogen fuel cells and any spots with insufficient cooling or even overheating of the stack. The cause of this phenomenon, certainly not desired for regular operation, is then disclosed using computer simulation employing a numerical model in the Ansys CFX program. The results obtained through measurement and PC simulations are processsed to suggest a suitable solution to enable a more effective and safer operation of the stack of hydrogen fuel cells subject to research within the hybrid power system.

Title: Integration of photovoltaic and wind power plants in low voltage networks using energy storages
Source title: Proceedings of the 9th International Scientific Symposium on Electrical Power Engineering, ELEKTROENERGETIKA 2017

Abstract: This paper deals with most common problems which occur when low voltage grids are highly penetrated with distributed generation based on renewable energy like solar or wind. Model of distribution grid in central Europe based on real data with high share of renewables is created and impacts are observed. Authors: Vašíček J., Vítek M.
Title: New ways of providing ancillary services in a power system
Source title: Proceedings of the 9th International Scientific Symposium on Electrical Power Engineering, ELEKTROENERGETIKA 2017
Affiliations: Czech Technical University, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Prague, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Vašíček, J., Czech Technical University, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Prague, Czech Republic; Vítek, M., Czech Technical University, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Prague, Czech Republic
Abstract: This contribution focuses on new possibilities for balancing generation and load in an electrical power system. The ever increasing proportion of intermittent power sources (wind and solar) in the power system changes the basic paradigm of power engineering economics whereby instead of adjusting generation output to the demand at the time, the focus is shifting towards adjusting consumption based on the output of intermittent generation. That is the goal of the so-called smart grids, where the consumer will be adapting to intermittent generation by responding to price signals. In spite of or rather because of this, there will still be (at the moment, more and more) the need for power sources and appliances that will, at the dispatcher's request, quickly increase or decrease generation or instead of generators become consumers, i.e. their technical parameters enable them to maintain balance between generation and consumption and network frequency within set limits. On the generation side, these are primarily gas turbines and closed cycle gas turbines, pumped storage hydro stations, heat plants with turbines equipped with heat accumulators or accumulating heat into a heat distribution network and networks of CHPs (combined heat and power) also with heat accumulators supplying heat into buildings in a wide area, but centrally controlled. On the demand side, these are HDO systems (a form of ripple control in the Czech Republic) which control appliances that convert electricity into useful heat, which is easier to accumulate for water heating purposes, electrical boilers connected into heat networks and in the future also P2G systems using cheap electricity to break down water into oxygen and hydrogen. Being affiliated with current heat plants, they will utilize carbon from fossil or biofuel combustion for the methanisation of hydrogen and its injection into the natural gas network for the purposes of seasonal energy accumulation. Nonetheless, for accumulation of alternate current over the course of a day to a week it is still the best to make use of the benefits of pumped storage hydro power stations which remain to be a proven form of electricity accumulation in the grid. The vast majority of them are designed and constructed in mountainous regions so that they can take advantage of the differences in elevation of the landscape. This appears to be at odds with nature protection interests. The paper concentrates on a location of an active lignite quarry in the northwest of the Czech Republic, where the interests of nature protection would not be affected. From an economical perspective, in the case of a pumped storage hydro station, capital expenditure is key and therefore the paper also includes an assessment of the economic viability of the project, through the valuation of the effects resulting from the provision of ancillary services to the transmission system.

Authors: Kong P., Fang G., He C., Liu Z.
Title: Topology optimization of port wireless sensor network based on small-world network
Source title: 2017 International Conference on Circuits, System and Simulation, ICCSS 2017
Affiliations: School of Logistics Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, China
Authors with affiliations: Kong, P., School of Logistics Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, China; Fang, G., School of Logistics Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, China; He, C., School of Logistics Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, China; Liu, Z., School of Logistics Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, China
Abstract: Towards the characteristics of port monitoring and the particularity of network environment, an optimized wireless sensor network (WSN) topology based on small-world network was constructed, combining with the WSN topology. The model could reduce the average path length and improve the network node clustering coefficient, which could improve the efficiency of network communication, enhance security invulnerability and reduce energy consumption. Thus the overall network lifetime can be improved ultimately. In this paper, the WSN topology of port coal terminal storage yard and optimized WSN topology based on small-world network were designed. Then, the average path length and clustering coefficient of port WSN topology were compared before and after optimization. The results showed that the average path length was shorter and clustering coefficient was bigger after optimization. In conclusion, WSN topology optimization based on small-world network is valid in the intelligent port. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Dinglasan Fenol S., Caluyo F.S., Lorenzo J.L.
Title: Simulation and modeling of charging and discharging of supercapacitors
Source title: 2017 International Conference on Circuits, System and Simulation, ICCSS 2017

Authors with affiliations: Dinglasan Fenol, S., School of Graduate Studies, Mapua Institute of Technology, Manila, Philippines; Caluyo, F.S., School of Graduate Studies, Mapua Institute of Technology, Manila, Philippines; Lorenzo, J.L., College of Engineering and Information Technology, Cavite State University, Cavite, Philippines
Abstract: Supercapacitors is the new technology that can be used to replace the battery or in parallel with battery with its fast charge-discharge characteristics. Possible applications of supercapacitors are in renewable energy as sustainable energy storage and hybrid electric vehicle (HEV). This study focus on charging and discharging of supercapacitors and its behavior. Mathematical models of charging and discharging with the proposed equivalent circuits were simulated and compared with actual experiment simulation using potentiostat. The equation for approximated full discharge time of supercapacitors was also presented. Two commercially available supercapacitors with 4.7F and 3.3F capacitance and 2.5V were set-up in potentiostat using two-electrode mode. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Charging; Discharging; Leakage current; Supercapacitors; Voltage
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Charging (batteries); Charging (furnace); Electric batteries; Electric discharges; Electric potential; Equivalent circuits; Hybrid vehicles; Leakage currents; Supercapacitor; Voltage regulators; Actual experiments; Discharge time; Discharging; Potentiostats; Renewable energies; Simulation and modeling; Sustainable energy; Two electrodes; Secondary batteries

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: 2017 Information Theory and Applications Workshop, ITA 2017
Source title: 2017 Information Theory and Applications Workshop, ITA 2017
Abstract: The proceedings contain 42 papers. The topics discussed include: multidimensional index modulation in wireless communications; advances in DNA storage; on the high rate, independence, and optimal prediction assumptions in predictive coding; info-clustering: an efficient algorithm by network information flow; Poisson cluster process: bridging the gap between PPP and 3GPP HetNet models; low bandwidth repair of the RS(10,4) Reed-Solomon code; Reed-Solomon based globally coupled quasi-cyclic LDPC codes; on the Gaussian Z-interference channel; energy efficiency and resource allocation of IEEE 802.15.6 IR-UWB WBANs: current state-of-the-art and future directions; study on the coverage of fractional frequency reuse cells; generalized hessian approximations via Stein's lemma for constrained minimization; power-performance analysis of a simple one-bit transceiver; line coding for differential vector signaling; computing inter-encounter time distributions for multiple random walkers on graphs; integrated code design for a joint source and channel LDPC coding scheme; semantic compression for edge-assisted systems; and optimal one-bit quantizers are asymmetric for additive uniform noise.

Authors: Happe A., Wohner F., Lorünser T.
Title: The archistar secret-sharing backup proxy
Source title: ACM International Conference Proceeding Series
Affiliations: Center for Digital Safety and Security, Austrian Institute of Technology (AIT), Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Happe, A., Center for Digital Safety and Security, Austrian Institute of Technology (AIT), Vienna, Austria; Wohner, F., Center for Digital Safety and Security, Austrian Institute of Technology (AIT), Vienna, Austria; Lorünser, T., Center for Digital Safety and Security, Austrian Institute of Technology (AIT), Vienna, Austria
Abstract: Cloud-Storage has become part of the standard toolkit for enterprisegrade computing. While being cost- And energy-efficient, cloud storage's availability and data confidentiality can be problematic. A common approach of mitigating those issues are cloud-of-cloud solutions. Another challenge is the integration of such a solution into existing legacy systems. this paper introduces the Archistar Backup Proxy which allows integration of multi-cloud storage into existing legacy enterprise computing landscapes by overloading the industry-standard Amazon S3 protocol. .e paper provides multiple lessons-learned during implementation and concludes with a performance evaluation with traditional backup solutions utilizing redundant remote storage. © 2017 Association for Computing Machinery.
Author Keywords: Backup system; Cloud storage; Distributed system; Secret sharing
Index Keywords: Energy efficiency; Legacy systems; Back-up systems; Cloud storages; Data confidentiality; Distributed systems; Energy efficient; Enterprise computing; Industry standards; Secret sharing; Digital storage

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Energy and Sustainability in Small Developing Economies, ES2DE 2017 - Proceedings
Source title: Energy and Sustainability in Small Developing Economies, ES2DE 2017 - Proceedings
Abstract: The proceedings contain 25 papers. The topics discussed include: HADAS and web services: eco-efficiency assistant and repository use case evaluation; development of green technologies in complex territorial morphologies: an ecoconstructive approach; design and power production of small-scale wind turbines; analytical study of water turbine with fluctuating blades; towards autonomous reconfiguration in distribution networks: an approach based on finite state automaton models; Panama metro bus system and metro line 1: an externalities analysis of CO2 emissions spectre; photovoltaic system for self-consumption - an economic viability study; a multidimensional assessment of efficient lighting technologies in the industrial sector; novel safety and energy management functions to solar water heating systems; energy production forecasting for a wind farm composed of turbines with different features; net zero energy home including photovoltaic solar cells, wind turbines, battery energy storage systems and hydrogen vehicles; development of an ANN model to predict the electricity produced by small scale roof-top PV systems in Madeira island; fostering consumers' energy market through smart contracts; and performance of double pass PV/T combi solar collector with CPC: theoretical approach.

Authors: Xu R., Wang Y.
Title: Simulation of composite electric power for electric vehicles
Source title: 2017 IEEE International Conference on Mechatronics and Automation, ICMA 2017
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Tianjin Key Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, China
Authors with affiliations: Xu, R., School of Electrical Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Wang, Y., Tianjin Key Laboratory for Control Theory and Applications in Complicated Systems, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, China
Abstract: The combination of a supercapacitor with a large power and a conventional battery, the composite power supply will improve the performance of electric vehicles, such as low power density and short cycle times of the individual batteries. The use of parallel staggered technology in the DC/DC converter, the composite power supply topology has been changed, which will greatly improve the overall performance of the composite power supply. The fuzzy control method is used to manage the energy of the energy storage system, and the simulation model of the electric vehicle composite power system is built under the MATLAB / Simulink environment. Simulation results show that the use of supercapacitor - battery composite power system, you can combine the advantages of both of battery and supercapacitor, it improves the power of output of the electric vehicles and optimizes process of the battery's discharge. Supercapacitor played a 'cut peak fill valley' role in the process of simulation, battery has more effective protection. Therefore it enhances the electric vehicle power performance and energy efficiency. And it have better economic applicability. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Composite power supply; Electric vehicles; Fuzzy control; Parallel staggered
Index Keywords: DC-DC converters; Electric batteries; Electric discharges; Electric machine control; Electric power systems; Electric vehicles; Energy efficiency; Fuzzy control; MATLAB; Secondary batteries; Supercapacitor; Vehicle performance; Vehicles; Composite power supply; Composite power systems; Conventional batteries; Energy storage systems; Fuzzy control methods; MATLAB/Simulink environment; Parallel staggered; Supercapacitor batteries; Electric power system control

Title: 2017 4th International Conference on Advanced Computing and Communication Systems, ICACCS 2017
Source title: 2017 4th International Conference on Advanced Computing and Communication Systems, ICACCS 2017
Abstract: The proceedings contain 166 papers. The topics discussed include: a cypher query based NoSQL data mining on protein datasets using neo4j graph database; improved performance of two server architecture in multiple client environment; a survey on investigation of vital human parameters from photoplethsmography signal to predict the risk of cardiovascular diseases; auto-associative neural network for sparse representation based face identification; classification of breast cancer dataset by different classification algorithms; intelligent wide area monitoring of power system oscillatory dynamics in real time; a novel framework for extraction of landscape areas and automatic building detection in satellite images; a channel borrowing CAC scheme in two-tier LTE/LTE-advance networks; design and implementation of arithmetic and logic unit (ALU) using novel reversible gates in quantum cellular automata; strategy tree and fuzzy based cloud SLA change management; low cost and improved performance measures on filtering techniques for ECG signal processing and TCP/IP based monitoring using LabVIEW; challenges, protocols and case studies in design of reliable energy efficient wireless sensor networks; joint optimal sizing and placement of renewable distributed generation and energy storage for energy loss minimization; intelligent query processing from biotechnological database using co-operating agents based on FIPA standards and Hadoop, in a secure cloud environment; and unit selection based speech synthesis for converting short text message into voice message in mobile phones.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Journal of Physics: Conference Series
Source title: Journal of Physics: Conference Series
Abstract: The proceedings contain 309 papers. The topics discussed include: the investigation of quasi-characteristic radiation of electrons channeled along the charged axes in the crystals of zinc blende; the Monte Carlo simulation of electron transmission through Al2O3 nanocapillary; model for plasma jet-driven magneto-inertial fusion; van derWaals effects in GIFAD for light atoms on insulating surfaces; charge equilibration times for slow highly charged ions in single layer graphene; terahertz generation in crystal driven by two-color laser pulses; effects due to the induced potential in ultrashort laser interactions with Al(100) and Al(111) surfaces; on the beam emittance/brilliance of highly charged ions extracted from the Frankfurt 14GHz electron-cyclotron-resonance-ion-source in standard and enhanced (MD) mode; measurements of the kinetic-energy-release (KER) of vibrational cooled HeH+ and H3+ at the electrostatic Frankfurt low energy storage ring (FLSR); optical fields to control ultracold atomic/molecular collisions; lifetimes of ultralong-range strontium Rydberg molecules in a dense BEC; anisotropic blockade using pendular long-range Rydberg molecules; double differential cross sections for ion impact ionization of ammonia(NH3) and methane (CH4) molecules; interference in fast bare ions colliding with diatomic molecules; low-energy electron interactions with chromium hexacarbonyl Cr(CO)6; photoionization of neutral iron from ground and metastable states; low-energy outer-shell photodetachment of the negative ion of aluminum; B-spline R-matrix with pseudo-states calculations for electron-impact excitation and ionization of magnesium; inelastic squared form factors of the valence-shell excitations of hydrogen studied by high-resolution inelastic x-ray scattering; and photorecombination studies of highly charged tungsten ions at Shanghai EBIT.

Authors: Wersland S.B., Acharya A.B., Norum L.E.
Title: Integrating battery into MMC submodule using passive technique
Source title: 2017 IEEE 18th Workshop on Control and Modeling for Power Electronics, COMPEL 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, 7491, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Wersland, S.B., Department of Electrical Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, 7491, Norway; Acharya, A.B., Department of Electrical Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, 7491, Norway; Norum, L.E., Department of Electrical Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, 7491, Norway
Abstract: The modular structure and the many other advantages of the Modular Multilevel Converter makes it an attractive converter for Battery Energy Storage Systems, allowing the battery units to be distributed throughout the convert, connected in each submodule. However, such an arrangement results in large oscillating components in the battery current, which is harmful to battery performance and lifetime. In most literature this is solved using DC-DC converters as active interfaces between battery and submodule. This paper investigates a passive filter arrangement as an alternative solution to the DC-DC converters. Where the batteries are interfaced with the submodules using a passive filter that suppresses the fundamental component and control technique that injects circulating current to suppress second harmonic component. It is concluded that this passive technique could be an attractive solution especially where high reliability is of concern. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery Energy Storage System (BESS); circulating current injection; integrated split-battery; Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC); passive filter interface
Index Keywords: DC-DC converters; Electric batteries; Electric inverters; Energy storage; Power control; Power converters; Power electronics; Alternative solutions; Battery energy storage systems; Circulating current; Fundamental component; integrated split-battery; Modular multi-level converters; Oscillating components; Second harmonic component; Passive filters

Authors: Nademi H., Norum L.E., Wersland S.
Title: An accurate MPPT scheme for photovoltaic modular-based conversion units: A robust sensorless predictive approach
Source title: 2017 IEEE 18th Workshop on Control and Modeling for Power Electronics, COMPEL 2017
Affiliations: ABB AS, Industrial Automation Division, Oslo, 0603, Norway; Department of Electric Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, 7491, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Nademi, H., ABB AS, Industrial Automation Division, Oslo, 0603, Norway; Norum, L.E., Department of Electric Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, 7491, Norway; Wersland, S., Department of Electric Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, 7491, Norway
Abstract: This research presents a Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithm for a solar photovoltaic (PV) power station which is constructed based on modified circuit topology of the Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC). The proposed MPPT is featured with Optimized Finite-Control-Set Model Predictive Control (FCS-MPC) to provide continuous extraction of maximum solar energy. The estimation-based approach allows for elimination of the current sensors in PV panels unlike the well-proven MPPT methods, e.g., perturb and observe (P&O) and ripple-correlation control (RCC), where costly sensing devices are widely deployed. With developed control strategy, fast tracking response for the PV plant along with acceptable control bandwidth under solar irradiation transients and PV panels mismatch are achieved. The introduced circuit of power conversion has led to decreased number of solar cells and a 50% reduction of the energy storage sizing compared to the basic MMC configuration. The effectiveness of the discussed MPPT solution over the solar irradiance variations is compared with the both P&O and RCC methods. The behavior of the studied PV system is also evaluated under different operational scenarios through simulations to confirm the designed concept. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Maximum Power Point Trackers; Model Predictive Control; Multilevel Power Converter; Optimization problem; Photovoltaic generation; Sensorless operation

Authors: Sun Z., Hou X., Zhang D., Meng Z.
Title: Complex carbonate reservoir characterization using diffraction imaging dataset
Source title: SEG Technical Program Expanded Abstracts
Affiliations: State Key Lab for Petroleum Resources and Prospecting, China University of Petroleum, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Z., State Key Lab for Petroleum Resources and Prospecting, China University of Petroleum, Beijing, China; Hou, X., State Key Lab for Petroleum Resources and Prospecting, China University of Petroleum, Beijing, China; Zhang, D., State Key Lab for Petroleum Resources and Prospecting, China University of Petroleum, Beijing, China; Meng, Z., State Key Lab for Petroleum Resources and Prospecting, China University of Petroleum, Beijing, China
Abstract: In north-western China, complex carbonate reservoirs have enormous potential for detection of oil and gas. Due to their significant depth (deeper than 6000 meters) and age-old history of sedimentation, the matrix porosity of carbonate reservoirs in Tarim Basin is usually less than 2%. The main storage spaces for complex carbonate reservoirs are secondary dissolved pores and fractures that are dominated by visible dissolved caves, fractures and weathering crust. As seismic diffractions carry valuable information related to these geological structures and discontinuities, diffraction imaging is an effective tool for this type of reservoirs. In this paper, we apply diffraction imaging technique in a study area of Tarim Basin and make comprehensive analysis of weak diffraction energy from different perspectives. The basic function using diffraction imaging dataset is for more accurate detection of dissolved caves, which has been emphasized in recent years. One step further is to utilize weak diffraction energy for fault system recognition. Two more issues are involved here when using diffraction imaging dataset: It is found that weak diffractions may cast some new lights on reservoir connectivity analysis, which is crucial for oil and gas development stage. Besides, weak diffractions also give some clues between well production and reservoir scale. © 2017 SEG.
Index Keywords: Carbonation; Caves; Diffraction; Geophysical prospecting; Petroleum prospecting; Petroleum reservoirs; Carbonate reservoir; Diffraction energy; Diffraction imaging; Matrix porosity; Oil and gas; Pores and fractures; Reservoir characterization; Storage spaces; Tarim Basin; Western China; Dissolution

Authors: Wilks M., Wuestefeld A., Oye V., Thomas P., Kolltveit E.
Title: Tailoring distributed acoustic sensing techniques for the microseismic monitoring of future CCS sites: Results from the field
Source title: SEG Technical Program Expanded Abstracts
Affiliations: NORSAR; Christian Michelsen Research
Authors with affiliations: Wilks, M., NORSAR; Wuestefeld, A., NORSAR; Oye, V., NORSAR; Thomas, P., Christian Michelsen Research; Kolltveit, E., Christian Michelsen Research
Abstract: Distributed Acoustic Sensing (DAS) is an emerging technology with great potential for microseismic monitoring of induced seismicity. Despite this potential and the advantages it presents over conventional geophone arrays, challenges remain regarding geometrical sensitivity and noise-floors. Furthermore, there has been little application of DAS systems at Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) injection sites. Here, we present the results of hammer blow field experiments, in subzero conditions using a single cable DAS recording setup. We test different data processing routines and compute Signal to Noise Ratios (SNRs) in the time and frequency domains. We find that most energy is observed in the 20-600 Hz band and that SNR ratios are approximately half those of geophones, which record simultaneously. An STA/LTA automated trigger detection routine performs well for the majority of the DAS recording channels but with some detections not defining the expected hyperbolic move-out with distance for common arrivals. These likely represent later, secondary arrival phases, possibly reflections from the frozen-unfrozen ground interface. Despite this, using a single homogenous velocity model it is possible to locate the hammer blows to within 3.9 m of their actual locations. These encouraging initial results will be used to tailor the setup and acquisition parameters in further field and laboratory tests. This will ultimately lead to the preinjection site characterization and subsequent microseismic monitoring of active CCS sites in the future. © 2017 SEG.
Index Keywords: Acoustic noise; Carbon capture; Data handling; Digital storage; Geophysical prospecting; Seismology; Acoustic sensing; Condition; Emerging technologies; Field experiment; Geophone array; Hammer blow; Noise floor; Sensing systems; Sensing techniques; Storage sites; Signal to noise ratio

Title: Design of inductive pulsed current generator based on solid-state Marx adder
Source title: 2016 IEEE International Power Modulator and High Voltage Conference, IPMHVC 2016

Abstract: This paper presents a novel design of a pulsed current generator using an inductor as energy-storage component based on solid-state Marx adder, in which the structure of the basic unit in solid-state Marx adders is changed. After two times of energy conversion, this current generator produces pulses with a good flat, a fast-rising edge and a fast-falling edge, regardless of the impact that the resistive load changes in a certain range. The design principles are described and the control method is also given. The feasibility of the design was validated in experiments. © 2016 IEEE.
